story:
This campaign is being started to raise money for the Colon Cancer foundation we started in Spartanburg, SC (A Miracle For Mom Foundation http://www.sos.sc.gov/index.asp) .  The focus of our foundation is to raise money for my mother who has stage 4 colon cancer and others faced with battling colon cancer without adequate health insurance.  This serious condition plagues hundreds of thousands of Americans each year. My goal is to raise money for my mom's chemotherapy treatments which cost close to $125k yearly and continue to raise money to fund our foundation which will assist others with their medical expenses associated with this deadly disease.  We are Americans; and no honest, hard working, tax paying American should not have to die because they have little-to-no medical coverage. Who better to tell my mother's story than my mother herself, Dr. Betty Staggs.  Please read..Story below....

I was born on Groundhog Day some fifty or so years ago.  Daughter to two teenage parents not equipped to raise a new baby.  Lewis (Pop) and Aline Rice raised me from the time I came home from the hospital.  From that time own they were my parents and treated me as such.  I received very limited visits from my birth mother, however; she would send me boxes of clothes to ease her guilty conscience and try to soothe the emptiness I felt about being abandoned.  My birth fathers identity was an open secret to everyone.  He never claimed me publicly but his family, (brothers, sisters, etc.), embraced me with open arms.

I was a gifted child. (Yes I am bragging on myself here!) A Majorette in the marching band, head cheerleader for basketball, I could (and can) draw anything just by looking at it.   I was in a sense a classic overachiever. 

Being given away gave my self esteem a blow, no matter how many accomplishments I made in school, I still could not shake feelings of inadequacy that haunt me to this day.  It is, I am told the burden that many children given away face.  Why was I not good enough to keep? What made my own father deny me? At the age of 16 I tried to take my life because I felt myself a burden on everyone.  I took 100 aspirin.  God is good!  It was not my time.  Over the years I have had many near death experiences.  I believe nothing happens by accident.  My life is my testimony.  As you read on, you will see I am a survivor.  I made it. 

I entered an ill fated marriage at the age of 18 that gave me the greatest gifts in my life, my three children.

An artist at heart, I moved to Connecticut to finish school.  I moved in with my birth mother and her husband.   I worked and taught art.  My husband at the time had no job so I was the provider of our family.

I moved back to SC after a time to pursue my love of cutting hair.  My dad taught me everything about clippers.  I loved (and still do) making people look good! "A New You"! I used to go to the ladies home and do hair at no charge.  I would also go to the homebound and do their hair.  The nursing home had many patients whose families forgot about them, not me!  I loved to go there and do both men and women hair.  It gave me comfort to help and the people were so grateful it gave my heart a lift to do the little I could to help out.

I finished Cosmetology School and received both licenses, barber and cosmetology.  Shortly thereafter I joined the State Association of Cosmetologists, SCSCA.  From there, I became involved in and a member of the NBCL, Inc. The NBCL was fundamental in allowing me to obtain all of my advanced degrees.  I worked hard for and received my BA, MA, and a Doctorate from Chicago State University.  

Meanwhile my business was booming.  At one time I had upwards to 30 + clients per day.  I would get out of my shop at 10:30 to 11 at night.  Half of my clients could not pay me.  Maybe they were ill or they were laid off or their husband was.  I did not allow that to stop me from blessing them.  Sometimes a nice hair cut or "do" is all a person has to make them feel good.  I trained over 65 barbers at no cost and most opened up their own shops.  I have traveled all over the US and Bahamas teaching styling techniques and hair cutting techniques to various   I am still training people.  I love to see people do well, and having your own business is the American dream.  

I was approached to do a campaign/contest in Upstate South Carolina to encourage people to get screened for Colon Cancer.  From that campaign I received over 100 promise cards from people to get colonoscopy screenings.  I was not able to have one at that time because being self employed; I did not have health insurance. 

About a year later I started having stomach pains.  I thought I was gassy or maybe had indigestion.  I went in to the doctor and was then referred to an Oncology surgeon to have a possible cyst removed from my ovary.  Unknown to me cancer was suspected all along.  I underwent surgery on, January 5, 2011.  The diagnosis was shocking.  Cancer had started in my appendix and the organ exploded!  The surgeon took out the affected organ and some surrounding organs for good measure.  He also took out lymph nodes for testing.  Upon getting the results for those tests I learned that I had stage 3C colon cancer. Devastated is not the word for how I felt when I heard that news.  I felt my life was on hold.  The strength from my children was all I had to hold on to.  I was not informing anyone of my status.  I did not want pity or bad wishes.  I only wanted to deal with this privately, and live.  Chemo was something I could not avoid but the doctor did give me hope, a 60/40 chance that the cancer would not come back. 

I went on to live and thrive thinking that the worst of that ordeal was behind me.  I have given speeches about the effects of Colon Cancer on individuals with no insurance to the SC legislature. I even attained a license to become a licensed clown so I can continue to put smiles on peoples faces.  My stage  name is "Blinky the Clown".  My favorite quote; "Smiles are contagious".

Meanwhile my father, Lewis"Pop" Rice became homebound.  I now became responsible for his care as well.  The situation with him became such that he needed full-time care.  The caregivers hired took more than his check could cover so long story short, I had to move in.  He took me in an orphan when I was unwanted, loved me and asked for nothing in return.  This was the least I could do for him.  It is ironic, he pinned diapers on me, now it was my turn to return the favor.  He always said, "always treat people well, you never know who is going to bring you your last cup of water".  Sadly, after being blessed and blessing others for 97 years, my dad passed away November 8, 2012.

As a part of my treatment I entered a case study for people with colon cancer.  As a part of this study I was given medication every week and CT screenings every three months.  Three weeks ago, I found out that my cancer came back.  It grew from invisible to very large in a three month time span.  The prognosis is very grim.  The doctor gave me a life expectancy of 1.5 to 2 years.  I looked him in his eyes and asked about other options such as Cancer Centers of America.  He said, sure those are options but you have no insurance!  Imagine being told that in front of your children.  You have no hope because even though you have worked all your life, helped people all your life, you have no insurance so you can take this treatment or die.  That might not be what he said but that was certainly what I heard.  Not telling my children, I made up in my mind that I would not take the chemo that was the next course of treatment.  I was sure that it will take me out of this world.  They fought back.  "You are taking this treatment"!  I relented and agreed to begin the second course of chemo. 

Speaking to the Colon Cancer advocate gave me hope.  There is no expiration date on me.  I can live! There are people out there right now living with this disease that beat it and better!  I am going to be one of those people.  This is my testimony.  Just when I begin to get down about my circumstances, I realize that there is hope.  My children, friends, and family are helping out with different ideas of raising money so that I can afford to get a second opinion at another hospital and maybe alternative treatment.  This will not be an easy task but it is a very attainable one.  I am sharing this with all of the people who read this to say: I am one of you.  I could even be you.  I was told I am going to die.  I say NO!  I am going to live.  I have much more to do in this life.  I have more to give to others, more to teach, more to do.  I am not finished.  With everyone’s help my life and this fight will not be in vain. Your participation in this fundraiser will help me reach my goal. 

Millions of people live right now with no health insurance.  They make too much to qualify for state medical insurance and private insurance is priced out of their range.  Something has to change.

I now ask you to challenge yourself. Even if you can not afford to give to my fund, please forward my campaign and website to others in your circle. We are thriving to make national headlines with my story to make an impact in the fight against colon cancer and the uninsured.  Thanks for reading my story and I truly appreciate your support.

 

Sincerely,

Dr. Betty Staggs

www.miracle4mom.org  ***Under construction***
story_txt:
This campaign is being started to raise money for the Colon Cancer foundation we started in Spartanburg, SC (A Miracle For Mom Foundation http://www.sos.sc.gov/index.asp) .  The focus of our foundation is to raise money for my mother who has stage 4 colon cancer and others faced with battling colon cancer without adequate health insurance.  This serious condition plagues hundreds of thousands of Americans each year. My goal is to raise money for my mom's chemotherapy treatments which cost close to $125k yearly and continue to raise money to fund our foundation which will assist others with their medical expenses associated with this deadly disease.  We are Americans; and no honest, hard working, tax paying American should not have to die because they have little-to-no medical coverage. Who better to tell my mother's story than my mother herself, Dr. Betty Staggs.  Please read..Story below....
I was born on Groundhog Day some fifty or so years ago.  Daughter to two teenage parents not equipped to raise a new baby.  Lewis (Pop) and Aline Rice raised me from the time I came home from the hospital.  From that time own they were my parents and treated me as such.  I received very limited visits from my birth mother, however; she would send me boxes of clothes to ease her guilty conscience and try to soothe the emptiness I felt about being abandoned.  My birth fathers identity was an open secret to everyone.  He never claimed me publicly but his family, (brothers, sisters, etc.), embraced me with open arms.
I was a gifted child. (Yes I am bragging on myself here!) A Majorette in the marching band, head cheerleader for basketball, I could (and can) draw anything just by looking at it.   I was in a sense a classic overachiever. 
Being given away gave my self esteem a blow, no matter how many accomplishments I made in school, I still could not shake feelings of inadequacy that haunt me to this day.  It is, I am told the burden that many children given away face.  Why was I not good enough to keep? What made my own father deny me? At the age of 16 I tried to take my life because I felt myself a burden on everyone.  I took 100 aspirin.  God is good!  It was not my time.  Over the years I have had many near death experiences.  I believe nothing happens by accident.  My life is my testimony.  As you read on, you will see I am a survivor.  I made it. 
I entered an ill fated marriage at the age of 18 that gave me the greatest gifts in my life, my three children.
An artist at heart, I moved to Connecticut to finish school.  I moved in with my birth mother and her husband.   I worked and taught art.  My husband at the time had no job so I was the provider of our family.
I moved back to SC after a time to pursue my love of cutting hair.  My dad taught me everything about clippers.  I loved (and still do) making people look good! "A New You"! I used to go to the ladies home and do hair at no charge.  I would also go to the homebound and do their hair.  The nursing home had many patients whose families forgot about them, not me!  I loved to go there and do both men and women hair.  It gave me comfort to help and the people were so grateful it gave my heart a lift to do the little I could to help out.
I finished Cosmetology School and received both licenses, barber and cosmetology.  Shortly thereafter I joined the State Association of Cosmetologists, SCSCA.  From there, I became involved in and a member of the NBCL, Inc. The NBCL was fundamental in allowing me to obtain all of my advanced degrees.  I worked hard for and received my BA, MA, and a Doctorate from Chicago State University.  
Meanwhile my business was booming.  At one time I had upwards to 30 + clients per day.  I would get out of my shop at 10:30 to 11 at night.  Half of my clients could not pay me.  Maybe they were ill or they were laid off or their husband was.  I did not allow that to stop me from blessing them.  Sometimes a nice hair cut or "do" is all a person has to make them feel good.  I trained over 65 barbers at no cost and most opened up their own shops.  I have traveled all over the US and Bahamas teaching styling techniques and hair cutting techniques to various   I am still training people.  I love to see people do well, and having your own business is the American dream.  
I was approached to do a campaign/contest in Upstate South Carolina to encourage people to get screened for Colon Cancer.  From that campaign I received over 100 promise cards from people to get colonoscopy screenings.  I was not able to have one at that time because being self employed; I did not have health insurance.

I went on to live and thrive thinking that the worst of that ordeal was behind me.  I have given speeches about the effects of Colon Cancer on individuals with no insurance to the SC legislature. I even attained a license to become a licensed clown so I can continue to put smiles on peoples faces.  My stage  name is "Blinky the Clown".  My favorite quote; "Smiles are contagious".
Meanwhile my father, Lewis"Pop" Rice became homebound.  I now became responsible for his care as well.  The situation with him became such that he needed full-time care.  The caregivers hired took more than his check could cover so long story short, I had to move in.  He took me in an orphan when I was unwanted, loved me and asked for nothing in return.  This was the least I could do for him.  It is ironic, he pinned diapers on me, now it was my turn to return the favor.  He always said, "always treat people well, you never know who is going to bring you your last cup of water".  Sadly, after being blessed and blessing others for 97 years, my dad passed away November 8, 2012.

story:
Who are these nice people?

This is Betsy Cunningham and her grandbaby, J.W.

Betsy and Harold Cunningham are just the greatest people.  Everything for them is about their family and their community--Harold fought for our country in Vietnam, they rescue abandoned and abused animals, they've volunteered in their church community--they have given and given and given to all of us who know them.

Betsy's totally devoted to her family.  The only reason she went back to work was to pay for their health insurance, and even then she made sure she left for work after the kids got off to school, and she got home just in time to meet the bus.  Just this past January, the money coming in couldn't offset the premium anymore--they had to let the coverage lapse.

What happened to them?

Several weeks ago, Betsy had a stroke.  The doctors say she's a miracle, because with a blood clot the size of an egg invading the right side of her brain, she should be paralyzed and without speech, and yet she is neither.  In fact, with physical therapy and some critical medicines, Betsy should make a great recovery.

The bills, though...they are coming in fast.  Harold is doing everything he can to balance what's coming in with what has to go out to pay for Betsy's neurologist and time in the hospital, but he and Betsy need help.

It was hard for him to say yes to assistance--Harold's a really independent guy who's a great provider--but sometimes in life the most courageous thing you can do is let the people who love you do just a little to get you through a hard time.  And just a little from all the people who love this family will make a huge difference for them.

What you can do ...

Any contribution will help.  They've already been through the emergency room and multiple MRI's.  There have been several follow up trips to the neurologist.  Betsy's going to need physical therapy visits and speech therapy specialists for some time to come. 

Everything goes directly to Betsy and Harold.  We're asking for $14,000, though Betsy's expenses will almost certainly go far beyond that.  Again, they know they need some grace to help with these astronomical bills, but they don't want to accept more than they'll need.

Other Ways You Can Help

Any way you can get the word out will help...facebook, email, calls to friends and neighbors.  Many hands make light work, and just a few dollars from a whole lot of people can make all the difference to this hardworking family.  Also, please keep Betsy in your thoughts and prayers...send her lots of good healing energy.  It really works.

Please help our Betsy.  She's done so much for everyone else!

story:
So... I have Meniere's Disease

My name is Amanda, I have a chronic disease called Meniere's Disease.  It causes vertigo, dizziness, tinnitus (ringing in the ears), aural fullness, nausea, and pain in the ears.  I have had three surgeries and I am still disabled.  This disease has stolen so much from my life, most importantly my confidence and independence.  I applied for an assistance dog through an organization called Can Do Canines. 

I was accepted into the program on April 30th!  My dog will help me with mobility issues such as helping me up when I fall, helping me steady myself both in and outside of my home.  In addition to helping with other tasks such as retrieving, turning on and off lights, and other tasks many of us take for granted being able to do around the house. 

Can Do Canines  provide assistance dogs at no cost to the individual.  They are pretty selfless people.  I am asking you to dig into your pockets, couch cushions, and wallets to help me give back to an organization that is surely going to change my life for the better.  

Disabilities can strike anyone at anytime... what would you do to help your child, parent, sibling, grandparent, or best friend?  Would you give a few dollars to support an organization that could help in a way no other treatment can?

What I Need...

Anything you can give... $1 can make a huge difference to an organization such as this one.  It can take $25,000 to raise one dog.  Any and all money collected will go directly to this organization as a donation.

The Impact

This organization gives individuals with all kinds of disabilities the opportunity to take back their confidence and their independence.  The impact of donating to this organization is endless.

story:
There are few things more masculine in the world than a nicely kempt beard. In 2015, while discussing our love of all things manly, two brothers struck upon an idea: Why not create a line of men's grooming products that are designed for men who understand and take pride in their masculinity?

Whether you enjoy an elegant Mustachio, a trim VanDyke, or a full-fledged Face 'Fro, Beard Brothers wants to make a product for you. From the sultan of his home; to the captain of industry; to the debonair Don; we are the brand you'll need.

Unfortunately, like any endeavor, starting a business takes funds. That is where you come in! Your donation will allow us to purchase the necessary assets to advance our line of products, and create our initial customer base. Our needs include web development services, raw materials, and the manufacturing equipment for production.

Please, take a moment to invest in the future face-fuzz of yourself or someone you love. Thank you.

story:
Mason was a healthy 5 month old baby until August 3rd 2012 when he stopped breathing during his nap. Mason's parents havent left the hospital in 3 days. Staying with him 24/7.

Doctors have no idea what is wrong with Mason. All they know is that there is brain damage and all Mason's organs are failing and something is seriously wrong. Im running this campaign to help raise money for them so they can afford Mason's burial. He is not gone yet. But there is a very slim chance Mason will make it threw this. Even though everyone is still praying for a miracle. They are both young parents and dont have the money to afford it. Mason's parents ask that everyone prays for Mason. Were asking for any donations. $1, $5. Whatever is in your budget to give.


Mason's parents appreciate everyone for helping them at this time of need. Thank you all in advance.

story:
Martha Cothran has Hepatitis C, a liver disease that has affected 4.1 million people in the US. Over the years, she has pursued medical treatments and experimental drug therapies to stop the advancement of the disease. She has now exhausted all traditional forms of non-surgical therapy.

To know Martha, however, is to know that she is an eternal optimist and spiritually blessed individual who approaches even life's most difficult hardships with courage, hope, grace and faith. This circumstance is no different and in her next course of action with this serious disease, she has chosen to pursue alternative healing from a world renown healer John of God in Brazil.

The trip is long, the expenses are costly. This campaign is set up to help defray the cost of Martha's travel expenses this November for her trip to Brazil. We are casting a wide net in hopes of attracting a large amount of small donations. Every dollar will make a difference.

And if circumstances prevent you from giving a donation, then please bless her with your prayers. Your prayers and support WILL matter. THANK YOU for your generosity of spirit.

story:
My name is Keith Junor and recently I have had some emergency medical problems.

30 days ago I had a massive heart attack and spent 2 weeks in the hospital undergoing insertion of stent and kidney dialysis.

With hospital and medical bills now over $150,000, today I found out that I need to undergo eye surgery right away or risk blindness due to retina detachment caused by my Type 1 Diabetes.

I am trying to raise as much as I can, but need $10,000 as soon as possible for immediate eye surgery.

I have always been self reliant and was able to help many others, but now it is me that needs the help

This is not easy for me, but I must put aside my pride and allow others to help me. Ever since I had to close my mortgage company my income has dropped dramatically, on top of having to go through bankruptcy and foreclosure.

Please give what you can. You can donate amounts that are not preset. Thank you and God bless.

For those who don't have Paypal or Credit Cards you can mail a Cheque/check or Money Order donation:

KMFR                                           KMFR
c/o J. Reid                                    c/o K. Junor
31 Crosswood Lane,                       5300 NE 24 Terrace, 529C
Brampton, Ontario                         Fort Lauderdale, FL
Canada                                        USA
L6V 3M1                                       33309

story:
Lanney’s Story

Born on November 23rd, 1999, Lanney Phillips was barely out of her mother’s womb when she was diagnosed with Bilateral Retino Blastoma at just 6 months of age. Retino Blastoma is a rapidly developing cancer that develops in the eye’s retina (the light-detecting tissue). Lanney spent the next four months undergoing chemo treatments to fight the cancer, but doctors determined that her left eye needed to be surgically removed because the retina had detached as a result of the cancerous tumor.

After the surgery, Lanney went through laser treatment every month until she was two and a half, at which point she was sent to Philadelphia for radiation treatment.

At 3 years old, and after having completed 25 radiation treatments, she was pronounced cancer free!

Unfortunately, despite having beaten the cancer, her remaining eye required cataract surgery and a lens implant.

Fast forward 10 years and Lanney, now 13, is a 7th grader who, like many of her peers, needed braces. Unlike her peers, however, the radiation treatments she underwent as a child had deteriorated her jaw bones to the point that standard orthodontia treatment would be impossible.

No one realized that Lanney had spent her entire life eating on only the left side of her mouth. If doctors don’t act now, she will likely continue to lose bone mass in her jaws as she gets older.

In order to prevent this from happening, Lanney will need 3 implants, screws to hold her bottom jaw in place, bone graphs and further testing of the deteriorating bone. Doctors will also begin her on hyperbaric oxygen therapy to try to regenerate some of the healthy cells that the radiation treatment destroyed in the process of killing off the cancerous cells.

 

How can you help?

Despite having medical insurance, her parents Tommy and Lindsay Phillips must come up with $20,000 up front before the doctors or insurance will do anything to help Lanney. This is what led us to start this campaign. Lanney is a trooper to have gone through so much at such a young age, and we are humbly asking for your support.

We want to thank you in advance for any and all support you can contribute to Lanney.

Thank you!

Born on November 23rd, 1999, Lanney Phillips was barely out of her mother’s womb when she was diagnosed with Bilateral Retino Blastoma at just 6 months of age. Retino Blastoma is a rapidly developing cancer that develops in the eye’s retina (the light-detecting tissue). Lanney spent the next four months undergoing chemo treatments to fight the cancer, but doctors determined that her left eye needed to be surgically removed because the retina had detached as a result of the cancerous tumor.
After the surgery, Lanney went through laser treatment every month until she was two and a half, at which point she was sent to Philadelphia for radiation treatment.
At 3 years old, and after having completed 25 radiation treatments, she was pronounced cancer free!
Unfortunately, despite having beaten the cancer, her remaining eye required cataract surgery and a lens implant.
Fast forward 10 years and Lanney, now 13, is a 7th grader who, like many of her peers, needed braces. Unlike her peers, however, the radiation treatments she underwent as a child had deteriorated her jaw bones to the point that standard orthodontia treatment would be impossible.
No one realized that Lanney had spent her entire life eating on only the left side of her mouth. If doctors don’t act now, she will likely continue to lose bone mass in her jaws as she gets older.
In order to prevent this from happening, Lanney will need 3 implants, screws to hold her bottom jaw in place, bone graphs and further testing of the deteriorating bone. Doctors will also begin her on hyperbaric oxygen therapy to try to regenerate some of the healthy cells that the radiation treatment destroyed in the process of killing off the cancerous cells.
 
How can you help?
Despite having medical insurance, her parents Tommy and Lindsay Phillips must come up with $20,000 up front before the doctors or insurance will do anything to help Lanney. This is what led us to start this campaign. Lanney is a trooper to have gone through so much at such a young age, and we are humbly asking for your support.
We want to thank you in advance for any and all support you can contribute to Lanney.
Thank you!

story:
Summary

Hospice Angelus Taraclia is an NGO that provides free palliative care to terminally ill cancer patients in the Taraclia district of Moldova. Due to our largest funder, the Soros Moldova Foundation, closing its palliative care program in Moldova, we have been diligently searching for other funding opportunities. While the organization is scheduled to receive more funding in March 2015, it is currently without funding. 

To give you some context, cancer is the second leading cause of death in Moldova, and many people do not get early detection screenings. Thus, they are often diagnosed with cancer when it is too late to reverse the disease’s damage, and people often suffer in a great deal of pain without proper care and medications. In order to solve this dire issue, Angelus Taraclia began operations in 2009 with the introduction of a free home palliative care program. 

Angelus Taraclia is scheduled to sign a new contract with the National Health Insurance Company (CNAM) in March 2015, but until then, the organization is without funding. This is where your contribution comes in! The funds we raise through this Indiegogo Campaign will bridge gap funding until the organization receives funding in March. Our goal of $2,000 will cover a month and a half of Angelus Taraclia's expenses.

What We Need & Your Impact

Notably, in January 2014, the WHO adopted a resolution stating that governments should integrate palliative care into health systems and provide palliative care as a human right for those with terminal illnesses. Unfortunately, in the Republic of Moldova, there is little support from the government or CNAM to finance Angelus Taraclia’s expenses, including staff salaries, gasoline for home visits, and the free medical services and care that Angelus Taraclia provides to its patients and their families. 

Your contribution will keep the hospice running and give patients the ability to die with dignity, peacefully and surrounded by loved ones in the least amount of pain possible. Unfortunately, since Angelus Taraclia is not a registered 501(c)(3) in the United States, donations will not be tax deductible. That being said, whether we do not reach our fundraising goal or whether we surpass it, all of the money raised will go to benefit Angelus Taraclia and its beneficiaries. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Although we do not know the exact amount of support we will receive from CNAM or other long-term donors in 2015, your contributions will bridge gap funding for Angelus Taraclia's ongoing expenses. Every donation helps us over the next few months while we continue to search for other sources of support. 

If you cannot contribute, please SHARE our campaign on your social media sites with people you think who could. Every bit counts! On behalf of the hospice staff, patients, and their loved ones, we thank you for your help! :)

For more information, visit our website and Facebook page.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Maria Barnes.  I am energetic, fun-loving, positive, full of life and passionate about living a healthy lifestyle.  I live this passion as a naturopath doctor and fitness trainer and love helping others realize their full health potential.  I also happen to be fighting breast cancer.

Many people have been touched by the misfortune of cancer, either directly or indirectly.  The disease brings the obvious health issues, but also causes stressful situations that are not so apparent.  Cancer patients undergoing treatment are often unable to work and even with insurance, face overwhelming medical bills.  The stress associated with an inability to cover mounting expenses can have a negative impact on one's ability to heal. I have faced these challenges personally and want to offer a helping hand to others.

My desire to raise money is primarily for two reasons. The first is to help with my living expenses. Secondly, it’s to provide a small token of financial support to others fighting cancer and in need of assistance.


What We Need & What You Get 

My Goal is to raise $6000. You can help support my efforts by donating whatever you feel in your heart to give. With a minimum donation of $30 you also receive a Take Back Your Life "beelieve" t-shirt. No donation is too little or too much.  From that total, I will also pledge a portion to Georgia Cancer Center of America to help patients who cannot work and 10% to American Cancer Society Making Strides Breast Cancer Walk. Any funds beyond my goal will be used to launch the first annual "Beelieve" Empowerment Breakfast for women. This movement will be geared toward providing knowledge and resources for total health. 

The Impact

Coming together as a community your donation will help me "take back my life" and assist in eliminating fear and anxiety in exchange for the gift of love and light to someone else needing to "beelieve" in the power of giving. 

Other Ways You Can Help  

If you can't help financially, there are other ways you can contribute. I ask that you simply tell someone about my campaign by sending them here www.igg.me/at/teambeelieve.com Please feel free to use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word.   I’m also asking for you to join me on October 25th for the Making Strides Georgia Best Cancer Walk in support of my healing, for those who have passed on, and for those who cannot walk for themselves.  Be sure to first order a "beelieve" t-shirt here and then please click this link to register for the walk:

http://main.acsevents.org/goto/beelieve

Once your register, don't worry about the donation button in that registration site, I will donate for our team from the funds raised here. You will receive your shirt if walking on that day. If you are not walking, you will receive your t-shirt by mail in October. 

Thank you for your support.

story:
Short Summary

The Mark Webber Challenge is a 5 day adventure race taking us through Tasmania's rugged North West Coast, consisting of mountain biking, trail running, kayaking, orienteering and other challenging activities. 

Team Macks Advisory, consists of Denis Perry and Nicholas White. We are both athletes, from different sporting backgrounds and we are striving together to face the gruelling and adventures of the Mark Webber challenge.

We choose to compete to raise money for the Mark Webber Foundation, which supports numerous charities like, the cancer council, TLC for kids, Leukemia Foundation and the Tasmania Devil breeding facility at the Australia zoo.

The cancer council is close to both of our hearts with family members previously and currently suffering from the disease.

Whilst we will be over in Tasmania facing emotional and physical challenges throughout 5 days of racing, people across Australia are suffering and fighting various illnesses from months to years. You can make a impact on these people by donating to our cause, every donation big or small goes a long way.

What We Need & What You Get

Entry for the event is $9,900, half of which goes towards the Mark Webber Challenge foundation, the rest helps run the event. At the end of the day we hope to raise $10,000 for the foundation.

All donations are welcome however if you would like to become a sponsor of our team, in which includes huge media opportunities as the event is televised world wide.

The Impact

Denis Perry, has competed in the event for the last 2 years, and has seen the amount of support teams have contributed to the foundation, and how much of an impact it has had on the foundations. Our team would like to continue our support with all the foundations and organisations involved in this event such as all the other team business sponsors.

Nicholas White has not completed this challenge before but has donated his time to various other organisations such as the Loreto College Sony Camp Foundation; providing a service to the families and children involved with this camp.

Support us to support the under privilege or challenged people of today and give them a chance to live the life or receive the care they deserve from the money donated from you.

Other Ways You Can Help

To get our campaign across we need your help, not only through your donations but through spreading the word through social media. Please share and repost to your friends, families and work colleagues.

Please donate like we have donated our time for this trust worthy foundation, thankyou.

story:
1.  Mark Bowles, 32, is a mentally challenged veteran, living in Minnesota. He has epilepsy as well as post traumatic stress disorder (PTSD). In addition, Mark suffers from repeated traumatic brain injuries sustained in (1) a car accident while he served in the armed forces, (2) a jailhouse assault when Bowles resisted rape by another inmate, and (3) a fall while dizzy and weak, possibly because he was overly medicated in Anoka County Jail. Mark's injuries are so severe that his brain is now in irreversible atrophy, which is expected to be fatal.

2.  During the week ending June 28, 2014, Mark Bowles was wrongly convicted of the "crime" of having brain injuries. Mark experienced epileptic seizures that frightened a hospital employee after he emerged from a coma caused by an assault against him in Anoka County Jail. The woman was attempted to move away from Mark during his epileptic episode; she fell and bumped her own head. Unfortunately, Mark was falsely accused of assaulting the timid woman, who obviously should not be working with people who have epilepsy or traumatic brain injuries. Mark was allowed to present NO defense whatsoever during his trial. Mark's only possible defense was his diminished capacity caused by (1) traumatic brain injury and (2) his overdose on time-released psychotropic medications by the jail and/or the hospital. The jury was NOT allowed to hear either defense.

3.  Naturally, Mark's case must be appealed. That is why your help is needed to save Mark from wrongful incarceration. His sentencing date will be in August 2014. Mark desperately needs an accomplished appellate lawyer. In addition to contributing to Mark's legal defense fund, his mother, Diana Sprouse, invites your referrals for appellate lawyers at her email box DianaBeth1975@gmail.com.

4.  It is unconscionable that while Minnesota is holding Mark criminally responsible for an assault on hospital personnel that never happened, the inmate who allegedly attempted to rape Mark and beat him into a coma was never prosecuted for that assault, which was filmed at the jail. It may be perceived as politically incorrect to prosecute a gay inmate who attempted to rape a heterosexual young man. See both men pictured below (Lewis, the accused assailant is on the left, and Mark is in a coma on the right). All GLBTQ people who love justice are as appalled by this senseless assault and Mark's catastrophic injuries as you must be. He was a college student who enjoyed the outdoors before his attack. Now he suffers excruciating headaches and has to use a wheel chair and colostomy bag. His eyes are very sensitive to light, and he must wear shades indoors. Unless his brain atrophy can be stopped despite the doctor's negative prognosis, Mark will eventually die from his injuries.

5.  It may seem incredible, but some of our fellow citizens, even veterans like Mark, were actually railroaded into prisons and jails throughout America. Two Pennsylvania judges were convicted and sentenced for channeling hundreds of innocent children into their co-conspirators' juvenile detention facilities in exchange for $2.6 million. At least one child committed suicide. Former Judge Ken Anderson of Texas was disbarred and arrested when it was revealed that he deliberately withheld evidence of Michael Morton's innocence. As a prosecutor, Anderson caused Morton, an innocent, grieving widow and father, to be wrongly convicted and sentenced to prison. Morton suffered there for 25 years while Anderson's career accelerated. Anderson became a judge partly because of Morton's wrongful conviction. Not only was Morton cheated of the opportunity to raise his young, motherless son, but taxpayers were cheated of over $800,000 they paid to conduct Morton's criminal trial and incarcerate the innocent, young widow who remained imprisoned until he was middle age. There are many more examples of unjust jury verdicts that occurred because information was deliberately withheld that would have led to acquittals for innocent defendants like Mark Bowles. 

6.  After a trial during which U.S. veteran Mark Bowles was allowed to give no defense whatsoever and was therefore wrongfully convicted, he attempted suicide. Diana Sprouse sent an urgent message: "He slit his throat! Please pray!" Mark was convicted by a jury that was denied hearing any defense he could have given for allegedly assaulting a nurse in his hospital room. Defenses related to Mark's diminished capacity were reportedly squashed by Judge Frank Kundrat. The jury sent questions to the court, including: (1) Was Mark Bowles mentally ill? 
(2) Was Mark Bowles on medication that may have contributed to his offense? 

7.  The correct answer to each question was yes, but Judge Kundrat refused answers for the jury's questions. He cautioned the jury about considering anything that was not presented at trial, which was zero defense for the defendant. Mark is presently hospitalized under an armed guard like an animal following his unsuccessful suicide attempt. He was wrongly convicted of attacking medical personnel when the truth is he had an epileptic seizure that frightened a nurse who fell and bumped her own head. 

8.  Mark fears dying in prison from (a) his present brain injuries, (b) another overdose of prescription medications distributed by uninterested, unskilled prison personnel, or (c) while fighting off more jailhouse rapists. Mark said he would rather die now than suffer torture and brutality possibly for years and then die anyway of his brain atrophy. It is incredible that a U.S. veteran with traumatic head injuries and just out of a coma, would be so harshly punished for having epileptic seizures -- unless one realizes that such injustices happen often since many American prisons and jails were privatized and must be kept at a certain occupancy level.

9.  America presently has more than 1.25 million mentally ill inmates who comprise over 60 percent of the nation's prisoners in solitary confinement -- a cruel practice that the United Nations has labeled as torture. The wrongful conviction of Mark Bowles, a U.S. veteran and PTSD and epileptic patient, helps explain how that happened. The nurse who fell and bumped her head should hold the hospital responsible for sending her into a situation she was untrained to handle. She fully recovered, but unless you help Mark Bowles have a competent appellate lawyer, he and his mother may never recover from the horrors that they suffer in the Minnesota justice system. Please give generously to the "Mark Bowles Legal Defense Fund." What if Mark were your son or brother?

10.  Nine(9) numbered paragraphs appear before this point. Note: This writer tried to add a photo of Mark Bowles before he received the traumatic head injury in Anoka County Jail when resisting rape but had trouble sharing the picture. See such photographs at the first link below in the "Dog Justice for Mentally Ill" article, where you can also access another radio interview with Mark's mother, Diana Sprouse. The first reference below was "repaired" July 5. 

Three(3) References (Links should open in a new window)

Mark Bowles: Prosecuted for Epileptic Seizures (in "Dog Justice" blog) 
http://dogjusticeformentallyill.blogspot.com/2014/06/mark-bowles-prosecuted-for-epileptic.html

Ken Anderson vs. Justice and Michael Morton (in "Legal Victories" blog)
http://legalvictories.blogspot.com/2014/01/anderson-v-justice-for-morton.html

Kids4Cash Scandal in Pennsylvania (in "Wikipedia")
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kids_for_cash_scandal

story:
We need your help! 

Flyers and binders and zines...oh my!   Neatly filed folders and snacks piled so high! Bus tickets for those who don't live so near, and those little devices to look in your ear! All of these things that we wish to provide, to help our community and clinic continue to thrive!  

We are a community driven wellness space in Vancouver, BC, serving trans* and gender diverse people.  We receive no government funding and depend largely on donations to stay up and running!   (For more info, go to cwhwc.com!)  

Making a donation this month will help us to continue to provide volunteer medical & nursing care, hormone and surgical support, counselling, nutrition advice, legal advice, peer support, yoga, nutrition support and nutritious community meals to our trans* communities.  

This holiday season, consider showing some love on behalf of trans* and gender diverse folks in your life and make a donation! Here is where your funding will be used:


What We Need & What You Get

Basic wish list:

$ 20 - $ 40 buys books of transit tickets (one package lasts about 2 months)

$ 20 - $ 40 covers the cost of a cab ride to/from clinic or to/fro hospital for clients 

$ 25 pays for our medical billing costs for one month

$ 35 pays for one clinic's worth of snacks

$ 50 pays for one month of medical supplies from REACH

$ 50 pays for 2 months worth of printing educational materials for our clients (including zines like Fucking Trans Women)

$ 100 buys one year of website registration

$ 150 covers the cost to rent sound equipment for one fundraiser


"Dream-big" wish list:

$ 250 Electrolysis booster package for our clients in need

$ 500 Cost of food and supplies for one large community kitchen event

$ 10,000:  Approximate cost of Electronic Medical Record to improve our clinic's efficacy and organization & better meet the needs of our clients!  

$ _______ : Our very own health centre space! (one day...)  

Every little bit helps &

All funds raised will go directly to the clinic!


The Impact

Our clinic is run by and for our trans and gender diverse community.  We aim to celebrate all forms of gender identity and expression, and build wellness from all perspectives: physical, emotional, and social!  We try to break down institutionalized cis-sexism and transphobia in our health and community spaces.  Each donation will help keep our clinic space up and running!  


Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this link wherever you can!  Help get the word out about our services!  

Also: are you a trans* community member who wants to give back to the community? Have skills or general fabulousness to contribute?  Contact us at:  contactus@cwhwc.com and let us know!
story_txt: We need your help! Flyers and binders and zines...oh my!   Neatly filed folders and snacks piled so high! Bus tickets for those who don't live so near, and those little devices to look in your ear! All of these things that we wish to provide, to help our community and clinic continue to thrive!  We are a community driven wellness space in Vancouver, BC, serving trans* and gender diverse people.  We receive no government funding and depend largely on donations to stay up and running!   (For more info, go to cwhwc.com!)  Making a donation this month will help us to continue to provide volunteer medical & nursing care, hormone and surgical support, counselling, nutrition advice, legal advice, peer support, yoga, nutrition support and nutritious community meals to our trans* communities.  This holiday season, consider showing some love on behalf of trans* and gender diverse folks in your life and make a donation! Here is where your funding will be used:What We Need & What You GetBasic wish list:$ 20 - $ 40 buys books of transit tickets (one package lasts about 2 months)$ 20 - $ 40 covers the cost of a cab ride to/from clinic or to/fro hospital for clients $ 25 pays for our medical billing costs for one month$ 35 pays for one clinic's worth of snacks$ 50 pays for one month of medical supplies from REACH$ 50 pays for 2 months worth of printing educational materials for our clients (including zines like Fucking Trans Women)$ 100 buys one year of website registration$ 150 covers the cost to rent sound equipment for one fundraiser"Dream-big" wish list:$ 250 Electrolysis booster package for our clients in need$ 500 Cost of food and supplies for one large community kitchen event$ 10,000:  Approximate cost of Electronic Medical Record to improve our clinic's efficacy and organization & better meet the needs of our clients!  $ _______ : Our very own health centre space! (one day...)  Every little bit helps &All funds raised will go directly to the clinic!The ImpactOur clinic is run by and for our trans and gender diverse community.  We aim to celebrate all forms of gender identity and expression, and build wellness from all perspectives: physical, emotional, and social!  We try to break down institutionalized cis-sexism and transphobia in our health and community spaces.  Each donation will help keep our clinic space up and running!  Other Ways You Can HelpPlease share this link wherever you can!  Help get the word out about our services!  Also: are you a trans* community member who wants to give back to the community? story:
Amazing, gifted young is unable to train without your help. We need almost $10000 to make it possible to her reach goal and go to competitions this year.

She acheived this succcess only in three years of hard work and would be measerable to give up rhythmic gymnastics only because of shortage of finacial possibilities of her family. Our family work hard to provide everything we can, but it is not enough.

In these three years she received 33 medals from interclub, national and international competitions. Main achievements are - 3rd places with hoop and ball in finals in the "Luxembourg Trophy 2014" in Luxembourg, Europe, 2014; 2nd place in all-around  (1 place with clubs and 2nd place with ball in finals ) in the "Айголек" in Almaty, Kazakhstan; and 2nd place in all-around in Novosibirsk , Russian Federation, 2012.

For now we need finance for her basic needs as monthly payment for rhythmic gymnastics and participation in three provincial competitions. Our immediate budget in Canadian Dollars is:

Trainings      $5600

Provincial competition costs  $750 (3)

Western Regionals $1500

Equipment   $300

Music production $400

Second hand leotard $150

With your generous donation will help provide our daughter opportunity to do a sport she loves. Our daughter industrious, reliable, kind and responsible, and would be thrilled to be continuing her training. Thank you!!!

story:
Nanny Meal is a Low Allergenic, Complete Nutritional Drink for Kids ages one and older. Formulated by a Naturopathic Doctor and Mom.

Nanny Meal is an easy to digest, instant (powdered) Nutritional Drink for kids ages one and up.  It contains over 65 nutrients, including:  amino acids, vitamins, minerals, essential fatty acids, fiber, pre- and probiotics. Most instant drinks contain top allergens such as cow dairy, soy, and corn.  Nanny Meal is unique because it contains goat milk ingredients.  Goat Milk is consumed more than any other milk worldwide.  It is biochemically more like human milk and thus easier to digest.  Nanny Meal contains NO added sugar, NO artificial sweeteners or flavors, NO GMO ingredients, NO grains or gluten, and NO petrochemicals. 

Unlike most protein powders that use high heat processing, the goat milk products in Nanny Meal were gently dehydrated using variable low heat methods to retain nutritional integrity.  To make Nanny Meal a complete "meal", I formulated and added a blend of vitamins and minerals not found in goat milk. All the ingredients in Nanny Meal were carefully researched and  selected based on method of processing, potency, and purity.

Health-conscious parents agree there are times when good nutrition is unavailable or when extra nutrients are required.  Nanny Meal is a healthy option for special needs children relying on liquid nutrition.  If your child skips meals, is a finicky eater or needs a boost in between meals, Nanny Meal is the answer.  Nanny Meal is delicious with only the addition of water or children can make into a smoothie or a pudding like dessert in the mixer. 

Food Sensitivities and Allergies are a common problem today.

Allergic conditions are among the most common medical conditions affecting children in the United States.  Cow’s milk is the second most common food allergy in children in the USA.  In children under 3, cow dairy is the #1 food allergen.  Food allergies or sensitivities cause physical symptoms like chronic sinus congestion, throat clearing, headaches, stomach pain, eczema, asthma, and ear infections. Emotions and behavior can also be affected.  ADHD, irritability, and depression have been linked to negative to certain foods.

My daughter with eczema in 2006.

I originally created Nanny Meal for the child with allergies and food sensitivities. However, all children can benefit from the convenience of easily digestible, instant nutrition.  Most children in America are nutrient depleted because the American diet is refined and overly  processed and thus, nutritionally empty.  Children's foods are becoming more like toys, trinkets, and rewards rather than nutrition. Health-conscious and busy parents are looking for smart, low allergenic,  nutritious drinks for their kids.  

Who is Nanny Meal For?

  • Kids needing a Cow Dairy and/or Soy protein Alternative
  • Kids who Skip Meals
  • Active Kids
  • Underweight Kids
  • Kids needing more Dietary Protein
  • Children on Liquid Diets
  • On -the-Go Kids
  • Malnourished Kids
  • Finicky Kids

Why Goat Milk is best?

Consumers of goat milk frequently report beneficial health outcomes after switching from cow's milk to goat milk.  Some benefits include:  improved digestion and gut health, reduced mucus production, and resolution of chronic skin problems.

Goat Milk is the most commonly consumed milk in the world and most like human breast milk. It has a much lower allergenic potential compared to cow milk.  Unlike cow milk, the protein structure of human milk and goat milk are very similar.  It is naturally homogenized, contains smaller fat particles, less lactose,and 89% less Alpha-s1 casein than cow milk. Alpha-s1 Casein is a common allergen in cow milk.  Lastly, Goat milk contains Medium Chain Triglycerides (MCT's) and Prebiotics.  For these reasons, goat milk is less allergenic than cow milk and tolerated by most people.

Pasture-Raised Goats

The Goat Milk products are from healthy, grass fed, free-range goats that graze on pesticide free and chemical free pasture 365 days of the year.  They are offered hydroponically sprouted barley only during milking season. Gluten is only found in the barley seed and not the grass.  The goat milk products in Nanny Meal do not contain gluten.

Pasture Raised, Healthy, Happy Goats!

How is the goat milk in Nanny Meal processed?

The goat milk ingredients in Nanny Meal are processed using a unique, dehydration method called Window Refractance Drying.  This is a low temperature drying method which applies minimal and variable heat sources to retain nutritional integrity. Infrared light, rather than direct extremes of temperature removes water from from food. Window Refractance unique drying process allows the powerful  probiotics and digestive enzymes to thrive from the lacto-fermentation or “pre-digestion” process. Relying on the conductivity of water together with the properties of infrared and the refractance of light is the preferred method for preserving the precious nutrients found in whole foods.  

Nanny Meal (vanilla)

Environmental Friendly Container 

Nanny Meal will be packaged in a sustainable and biodegradable container called the Earth Bottle.  This container is made from plant materials and renewable natural resources.  Earth Bottles contain no petroleum products.  I will be one of the first companies to showcase this environmentally friendly container.

Nanny Meal On-The-Go


Nanny Meal at the Beach

Nanny Meal at school

Take Nanny Meal on vacation, camping, hiking, grandma’s house, athletic event, or to school. 

How to Make a Nanny Meal Smoothie


Nanny Meal is kid approved and fun for kids to make! In addition to Nanny Meal, the only needed ingredients are water and a drinking container with a lid.  The Nanny Meal Smoothie has been well received so far and we are still experimenting with different recipes for the Nanny Meal smoothie.

The Nanny Meal dance...just add water!


Rewards:  WIFM

Reward:  Nanny Meal single serving packets


Reward: Nanny Meal Coloring Posters


Reward:  Nanny Meal

Reward:  Baby Goat Plush Stuffed Animal with Logo in JuteTote Bag.


Reward:  Naturopathic Consultation and Custom Formulated Nanny Meal


Testimonials

Nanny Meal for Special Needs Children




We thank you for supporting Nanny Meal!

Risks and challenges

I will be purchasing the earth bottle container to package Nanny Meal in. The earth bottle is still in the final stages of production. The projected time of availability is early fall, so If it is not completed by October, I will not be able to package it as planned.

There could be a delay in any step of the business paperwork processing and will need to be addressed before moving forward.

story:
In Aug. 2011 at age 48 I was diagnosed with stage 4 colon cancer that had spread to my liver.Later that month (after I had a port put in) I started on chemo,I had every bad side effect that comes with it.In Sept.my family drove from Colorado to Austin Texas and convinced my wife and I to move so that they could help care for me.So we moved to a small town in Colorado (where I grew up). My new doctors wanted to go with surgery so I got off chemo and in Jan 2012 I went into surgery.They removed 9 inches of colon and half of my liver.While I was recovering in ICU my colon burst and I went into septic shock (they thought they lost me twice). I went back into surgery where they had to put me on a colostomy bag.I spent 4 weeks in the hospital.I had to go back numerous times with complications.In May 2012 I had another scan and it showed a spot on my liver and one on my colon.So back on chemo for the liver with radiation for the colon.In Sept. I was back in the ER with stomach pains,they had to take out 12 inches of lower bowel (the radiation had fried it along with part of my bladder). He tried to reverse my colostomy while he had me opened up but couldn't because the scar tissue was too hard,he also noticed that the spot on my colon was scar tissue (26 days of radiation for nothing). In Jan.this year I was back on chemo for 6 treatments,in May another scan showed the spot on my liver had grown.So chemo wasn't working radiation or surgery wasn't an option and I was given about 1 year to live (AGAIN). My doctor sent all my info to a doctor in Denver for a procedure called SIR-Sphere's but he didn't think I was a candidate for it.A couple weeks later I get a call from Denver and I was a candidate but for a procedure called Chemo-Embolization.I had this done in July and had a scan last month.With that scan and blood work (Including genetic testing) they think I might be in remission.So I figured since I might be around for a while more let's see if we can have my colostomy bag reversed.After talking to my doctor he thinks it's a very good possibility and I go in for surgery next week OCT.24th.
Now the reason for the money is when we left Austin we left my wives daughters (who have been mine for the last 18 years),granddaughters,grandson,brothers,sister and her mom,not to mention both of our jobs (witch we both still have when we get back). We moved here to get me well and now that I am it's time to go back.As you can probably guess we've blown through our savings and can't afford to move back on our own.We don't like asking for help but sometimes life leaves you no choice.I know remission may last years or months so if it does come back and take me I just want to make sure my wife is back with her family.
Well that's my story.It's been a rough couple of years but I'm looking forward to the future.

story:
Hello!  My name is Jes Bodimer.

My education is in Exercise Science.  I have experience in working with people and their goals.  My mission is to help people be(come) healthy and happy through behavior modification.  

This campaign to is help purchase an all women's circuit gym in order to allow the activity of its current members, and also give rise to a movement in fighting obesity, educating people about preventative health care, and in the enhancement of people's lives.  

As a contributor you will help me in my efforts to raise awareness, provide education, and support in the fight against obesity.  You can aid me in the enhancement of other peoples quality of life and you will be supporting a cause that will contribute to decreasing people's risk of disease.  If you've ever questioned the means to being the healthiest version of yourself, you'll be supporting assistance in those answers.  If you've ever struggled with the action and mind set of healthy behavior, you'll be supporting motivation and encouragement in that area.  

We need each other in this journey of healthy living!  Help me continue the movement of providing support, encouragement, and motivation toward healthy, happy living!  

I need you...

To get started!!!  $5,000:

$3,000 will be to purchase all the equipment, and business material that is keeping Aspire afloat currently. 

$1,000 is to pay the first month's lease and bills.  

$1,000 is capital money to purchase things such as an LLC, minimal equipment and/or upgrades to aspire, and marketing / promotion to get the word out!

I have saved 25% of all my personal training earnings for 3 months and will be able to cover the security deposit. 

Five thousand dollars is a lot of money, but when considering most business start ups, its actually a much smaller number.  This is one reason I am turning to an indigogo campaign rather than applying for a loan, or grant. My goal is to reach out to as many people as possible for this cause, and this time sensitive opportunity will get the ball rolling in the right direction!  

I can use any amount that you donate, and if you aren't able to give in the form of money, your word of mouth and/or social media share will help!  Recommending my services to anyone who you think I can help will also be very, very helpful :)  Thank you so much to any of you who are able to help me out in any way!  Thank you so much to those of you who have already helped me get this far in the process!!!

This TED talk video helped me be fearless in asking for assistance with this dream: Amanda Palmer - The art of asking 


In return I can offer my knowledge, experience, and support to help you reach YOUR goals!

Healthy & Happy Bodi--Personal Training--Services Defined:

Personalized Online Workouts are sent to you via email, and are in a spreadsheet layout.  You will find your prescribed workout tailored specifically to you and your workout environment with number of sets, reps, and suggested resistance to use.  Links to instructional videos are provided along with any additional information needed in order to perform the workout.  There is an open door for questions and communication about the workout or any other health related questions that come up.  Check out a sample workout: Sample Online Exercise Prescription. So you can have these made for anytime, anywhere, and master them in your own time.  The accountability comes from your feedback directly within the spreadsheet of how many sets, reps and with what resistance you used, emailed back to me.  This is also how you'll progress with each Personalized Online Workout!!!


In-Person Training sessions are arranged by you and I.  Each session lasts 60mins.  It consists of exercise based on your goals and also conversations that are based on your goals.  I'll be right by your side motivating, educating and encouraging you through the exercises, and will be talking with you about your goals.  Constant strategies are developed; as our lives and situations change so often, its important for your goals and objectives to also change.   


Behavior Modification Counseling is that extra mile and attention toward being your healthiest self.  This counseling will involve pinpointing behaviors that are keeping you from accomplishing your goals, and developing strategies to modify those behaviors.  These sessions are arranged by you and I, and last 30-60mins.  


SO, NOW THAT THOSE ARE DEFINED....


here's what you can take advantage of by helping me out!

  • Donation of $10.00 qualifies you for a personalized online workout!
  • Donation of $50.00 qualifies you for 2 sessions of in person training or 3 personalized online workouts
  • Donation of $150.00 and qualifies you for a month of in person training or personalized online workouts for one month (2x/week)
  • Donations of $500 and up qualifies you for 2 months (or more) of, in person training (2x/week) or personalized online workouts plus Healthy and Happy Bodi -- Behavior Modification Counseling

*being healthy isn't easy... nor is it easy to push on people.  These perks are available if you want to take advantage of them, not required.  


Thank you so much for any help you are able to give me.  I believe in this cause, and will be working toward many goals and objectives to make a difference for a very long time.  


Sincerely, 

Jes Bodimer

Hello!  My name is Jes Bodimer.My education is in Exercise Science.  I have experience in working with people and their goals.  My mission is to help people be(come) healthy and happy through behavior modification.  This campaign to is help purchase an all women's circuit gym in order to allow the activity of its current members, and also give rise to a movement in fighting obesity, educating people about preventative health care, and in the enhancement of people's lives.  As a contributor you will help me in my efforts to raise awareness, provide education, and support in the fight against obesity.  You can aid me in the enhancement of other peoples quality of life and you will be supporting a cause that will contribute to decreasing people's risk of disease.  If you've ever questioned the means to being the healthiest version of yourself, you'll be supporting assistance in those answers.  If you've ever struggled with the action and mind set of healthy behavior, you'll be supporting motivation and encouragement in that area.  We need each other in this journey of healthy living!  Help me continue the movement of providing support, encouragement, and motivation toward healthy, happy living!  I need you...To get started!!!  $5,000:$3,000 will be to purchase all the equipment, and business material that is keeping Aspire afloat currently. $1,000 is to pay the first month's lease and bills.  $1,000 is capital money to purchase things such as an LLC, minimal equipment and/or upgrades to aspire, and marketing / promotion to get the word out!I have saved 25% of all my personal training earnings for 3 months and will be able to cover the security deposit. Five thousand dollars is a lot of money, but when considering most business start ups, its actually a much smaller number.  This is one reason I am turning to an indigogo campaign rather than applying for a loan, or grant. My goal is to reach out to as many people as possible for this cause, and this time sensitive opportunity will get the ball rolling in the right direction!  I can use any amount that you donate, and if you aren't able to give in the form of money, your word of mouth and/or social media share will help!  Recommending my services to anyone who you think I can help will also be very, very helpful :)  Thank you so much to any of you who are able to help me out in any way!  Thank you so much to those of you who have already helped me get this far in the process!!!This TED talk video helped me be fearless in asking for assistance with this dream: Amanda Palmer - The art of asking In return I can offer my knowledge, experience, and support to help you reach YOUR goals!Healthy & Happy Bodi--Personal Training--Services Defined:Personalized Online Workouts are sent to you via email, and are in a spreadsheet layout.  You will find your prescribed workout tailored specifically to you and your workout environment with number of sets, reps, and suggested resistance to use.  Links to instructional videos are provided along with any additional information needed in order to perform the workout.  There is an open door for questions and communication about the workout or any other health related questions that come up.  Check out a sample workout: Sample Online Exercise Prescription. So you can have these made for anytime, anywhere, and master them in your own time.  The accountability comes from your feedback directly within the spreadsheet of how many sets, reps and with what resistance you used, emailed back to me.  This is also how you'll progress with each Personalized Online Workout!!!In-Person Training sessions are arranged by you and I.  Each session lasts 60mins.  It consists of exercise based on your goals and also conversations that are based on your goals.  I'll be right by your side motivating, educating and encouraging you through the exercises, and will be talking with you about your goals.  Constant strategies are developed; as our lives and situations change so often, its important for your goals and objectives to also change.   Behavior Modification Counseling is that extra mile and attention toward being your healthiest self.  This counseling will involve pinpointing behaviors that are keeping you from accomplishing your goals, and developing strategies to modify those behaviors.  These sessions are arranged by you and I, and last 30-60mins.  SO, NOW THAT THOSE ARE DEFINED....here's what you can take advantage of by helping me out!

Donation of $10.00 qualifies you for a personalized online workout!


Donation of $50.00 qualifies you for 2 sessions of in person training or 3 personalized online workouts


Donation of $150.00 and qualifies you for a month of in person training or personalized online workouts for one month (2x/week)


Donations of $500 and up qualifies you for 2 months (or more) of, in person training (2x/week) or personalized online workouts plus Healthy and Happy Bodi -- Behavior Modification Counseling

*being healthy isn't easy... nor is it easy to push on people.  These perks are available if you want to take advantage of them, not required.  Thank you so much for any help you are able to give me.  I believe in this cause, and will be working toward many goals and objectives to make a difference for a very long time.  Sincerely, Jes Bodimer

story:
Edmond Woman With MS Undergoes Stem Cell Treatment

Posted: Jun 22, 2014 9:42 PM CDTUpdated: Jun 22, 2014 9:42 PM CDT

By Heather Hope, News 9

EDMOND, Oklahoma -

A former Edmond school teacher battling Multiple Sclerosis went to Chicago for a life-saving stem cell transplant. She's back in town now with her results.

Pamela Gooch says she's the first person with Progressive Relapsing MS to have this particular procedure done. And since the transplant, she's never felt better.

"That just terrible tiredness is gone," said Pamela.

Back to her old, playful self, Pamela says her recent stem cell transplant has given her a new life.

"I can take a nap when I tire and I feel rested, however before, I couldn't get out of bed," Pamela said.

For two years since her MS diagnosis, Pamela always felt drained as her immune system was attacking itself. She even chopped off all her hair before chemotherapy beat her to it.

5/3/2014 Related Story: OK Woman Shaves Head To Prepare For MS Treatment

And in a 20 minute operation only offered in Chicago, she got new stem cells placed in her body. It was a success, until she got a letter from her insurance company backing out of covering the $150,000 procedure and instead opting to pay only a 1/10 of it.

"Pay for the rest of our lives for it, this is what we're going to do."

Pamela proceeded on despite the high cost and seven weeks later, she's back home in Edmond. She got her pay-off in time spent with her two sons.

"I'm very excited to be home with my boys, and I have energy now that I can give to them in playing with them and cooking for them," said Pamela. "And my main concern is being here for my family and trying to make up for the two years where I wasn't always available because of the MS."

Due to the MS, Pamela had to quit her job as a Pre-K teacher.



NEW STRETCH GOAL: $40,000

Thanks to you, I’ve reached my original goal in just 12 days!

As it turns out, we found out the top of the mountain was not quite where previously thought…

On Tuesday, May 6, the day after beginning chemo treatments and three days after shaving my head…

THE INSURANCE COMPANY PULLED THEIR PLUG ON MY PRE-APPROVED STEM CELL TRANSPLANT BY PLAYING THE “TECHNICALITY” TRUMP CARD. 

The Impact

DEVASTATION.  LITERALLY. 

I’m working with an attorney and going after the insurance company but that will take time, which is sadly, something I don’t have at the moment. In April, five new active lesions were discovered on my brain and I began to have difficulty walking. 

In order to keep the stem cell transplant on schedule, the hospital needed $125,000 by May 15. Property was liquidated, extreme sacrifices were made BUT my family came up with the money. 

NEEDLESS TO SAY…

I HAVE A NEW STRETCH GOAL: $40,000

As promised, Dr. Lenny Henderson of Oklahoma City has graciously matched the first $5,000 donated to my Indiegogo campaign. We are off to great start and I'm in the process of sending out perks. 

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT.  I PROMISE TO MAKE YOU PROUD. 

Sincerely,


Pamela:  The MS Stem Cell Transplant Girl


PS: Here's some MEDIA COVERAGE from my Indiegogo campaign: 









Original April Post/Video:


One phone call, one moment . . . a single illness . . . can alter the course of a person’s life forever. 

Reality often dictates what we know to be true… we take our health for granted and then, inevitably, wonder why we did…  

On Friday, August 29, 2012, I learned this lesson with humbling humility. 

It’s not often your doctor asks you to meet him at his office, after hours, on his day-off. The words, “You have multiple sclerosis,” echoed in my mind.  

It made sense; the senseless confusion I’d been feeling, the inability to accomplish simple tasks or walk in a straight line, the overwhelming fatigue, repeated episodes of falling and consistently tripping over my feet. I HAVE MS! Not to mention actual brain damage which has even led to me having trouble speaking. 

I quickly decided, I was going to keep my life as normal as possible, for as long as I could. Including continuing to work as a teacher and talking care of my newborn son, who was barely 100 days old when I was diagnosed.

Less than two years have passed, already I have resigned from my teaching position and I'm no longer able to drive. New MS lesions were discovered on my brain indicating the medication I had been receiving. Nothing was working. 

Thankfully, my neurologist brought my case to the attention of Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. They’ve pioneered a revolutionary treatment for MS called Autologous Stem Cell Transplant, which resets my immune system to stop attacking itself. 

Chicago is the only city in the United States where this transplant is being done. This procedure pushes the limits of what we thought was possible for treating MS. While the doctors won’t technically call it “a cure,” their patients certainly do and most are able to go on and live normal lives again. As you can imagine, challenging limitations and creating a new future isn’t cheap. Thankfully, insurance will pay for the bulk of the medical costs; however the eight-week relocation for myself and a full-time caregiver is still quite expensive.

Asking for support is never easy. My family and friends have done so much and now that I’ve been approved for this life-changing procedure, this Indiegogo campaign’s purpose is to seize tomorrow’s opportunities. My target for this campaign is $15,000 – which would help to fund my portion of the surgery bills and the temporary relocation costs. Any post-goal donations made will be applied to my ongoing medical care and my annual follow-ups in Chicago. 

Expenses will include medical "extras" not covered by insurance, travel to and from Chicago, lodging, rental car, food and miscellaneous expenses, including child care for my two sons while I’m away.

Today’s problems should never prevent us from dreaming about tomorrow. I am 41 . . . I want to be able to function again, I want to be able to pick up my baby . . . and, most of all, I want to know I tried!

Dr. Lenny Henderson of Oklahoma City will match every donation of the first $5,000 donated to my campaign.   

Please spread the word about this campaign to your friends and family. You never know who could help make this miracle happen for me.

PLEASE SEE MY UPDATE VIDEOS

story:
This little girl, Aida was born on Christmas Day, up to 7 years she was a normal child and then, suddenly a cruel disease paralyzed her from the neck down.

Aida have a 9.5 cm tumor in the spinal column even between nerve centers, which caused her the paralysis from the neck down

The current status of this 9 yr little girl is very serious, she can barely move her lips, no longer feels her feet, nor hands, nor the rest of her body ... she just feels the pain. We need to help her now. A plasmafareza treatment, abroad to a specialized clinic could save this little girl but for this she needs money to pay all the expenses.

It seems, according to Romanian doctors that Aida is a special case with a very rare disease and therefore is an urgent call to all physicians in the world to help this 8 years young little girl .

Romanian doctors diagnosis ranges of spinal cord inflammation and tumor pathology and their prognosis is also very bleak.

Let's help together Aida, let's give her a chance for life! God bless her.

Update Nov 20, 2013 - Thank you all who donated till now!
