story:
The team behind the wildly popular* web site and Skepticality podcast segment, The Odds Must Be Crazy wants to go to Dragon*Con this year. Wendy Hughes and Jarrett Kaufman have even been offered an entire segment in the Dragon*Con Skeptrack during which to speak, tell jokes, read stories, and juggle live honeybadgers*.

But it turns out, once they did some research, that Atlanta (the location of Dragon*Con in case you were wondering why some random city name was relevant) is not close to Los Angeles at ALL and, worse yet, the airlines that fly from Los Angeles to Atlanta charge MONEY to ride in their shiny metal birds, even though according to the online schedules they were already planning to fly between those locations anyway, whether or not Wendy and Jarrett are on the plane. Crazy, right?! Also, the places nearby that are filled with beds and showers and toilets ALSO want people to pay to use them, even if they'd just be sitting there unused anyway. The insanity continues unabated!

So that's where YOU come in, you fine, attractive, brilliant, generous, freshly-groomed, well-dressed, philanthropic, gratuitously hyperbolic readers and listeners. They need your assistance in donating a little money each to help them cover these costs.

They're actually not asking for that much of their total costs, either. They've worked out some agreements between the two of them based on what they could each afford to contribute on their own, then averaged out those funds to split the additional needs between them so neither of them feels like a total mooch (ahem, Jarrett).

So please, toss them a few bucks here or there and help them speak at Dragon*Con and become best friends with Wil Wheaton and Nathan Fillion*.

*In their hearts and minds.

story:
Short Summary

 

  We are raising contributions for our son Tyler and other Type1Diabetic children.The contributions will be used to purchase a bus or other like vehicle for safe transportation to and from various Dr. appointments.With the end goal of getting these children in the new drug trial ran by Dr.Faustman.(see video)

 By helping us achive this goal you will be helping to get the new treatment approved faster and hopefully doing away for the need for daily insulin injections.How important is this?Imagine not having to get 5 or 6 injections a day.Imagine having to live with the fear of death on a daily basis.Or the fear of an insulin shortage.Children with Type 1 Diabetes only have 3 to 5 days without insulin before complications lead to death.

 

What We Need & What You Get

 We need to raise at least $5000 for the downpayment on the vehicle.All conrtributions go toward paying for the vehicle.If the contributions exceed the purchase price,then we will supply the bus with various medical equipment,medical supplies,insurance and maintenance.

Any addition contributions will go toward additional vehicles to help even more children.With the end goal being to get as many children in the drug trial as possible.The more data they get the faster this will make it to market and the general public.

The Impact

Diabetes is an over all horrible disease and should be considered an epidemic.It reduces lifespan by an average 15 years.6 people die from diabetes every minute.And it has been estimated that 1 out of every 3 people will have diabetes(all types) by 2050.Diabetes also reduces quality off life.Complications from diabetes can cause blindness,kindney failure,limb amputation,heart attack,stroke,coma and death.

Diabetes may not be a major concern for you yet.And hopefully this project will make sure it never is.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  Please help us get the word out by tweeting and give this a Facebook like.Please post us on your Blog or favorite forums.

   God Bless

The Ash Family

story:
My Story

Hi! My name is Kat and sometime in 2009 I was bitten by a tick. I would soon find that ticks are very powerful parasites: They have the ability to make you forget your name or phone number, say "lettuce" instead of "gasoline", cause debilitating pain and fatigue, make your facial muscles twitch uncontrollably, isolate you from your friends and family and leave you depressed, alone and broke. The cost of treatment for this highly controversial disease is in the tens of thousands...if you're lucky enough to be insured. 


The Impact

By helping raise the money I need to pay for the treatments for Late Stage Chronic/Neurological Lyme Disease, you're helping a 28 year old girl have a shot at a normal life again. You're helping a girl go back to her life of adventure and activism. I want to inspire the world to be active in their life and the world around them whether it be philanthropic, social activism, socially responsible media or creative business ventures like TOM's Shoes. Since I've gotten sick, I haven't been able to volunteer, fund-raise or pursue any other avenue of social responsibility. My wish is that I will soon be able to return to this. 


What You Can Do

The funds raised will go towards the cost of medical treatment for Late Stage Chronic Lyme Disease. Current treatments cost upwards of $1800 per month. My Dr has warned me of the possible necessity of a Port or PICC Line in order to administer daily IV infusions of Rocephin, which will increase the monthly cost of treatment by $1000. There is also roughly $5000 in lab bills, which I will scan copies of. The money I raise through this will go to medical expenses ONLY, NOT personal living expenses. 
 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this with your social network. No contribution is too small! Sharing my page on Facebook, Twitter or even email is simple, thanks to the share tools IndieGoGo has implemented!


About Lyme

For more information on Lyme Disease, please visit:

www.lymenet.org

www.lymedisease.org

Mission

Sit Down Frisbee is the World's first instructional heckling videos...by experts.

Our mission is to IMPROVE THE LEVEL OF HECKLING OF ULTIMATE TEAMS & PLAYERS IN THE CREATION OF ENGAGING INSTRUCTIONAL HECKLING VIDEOS CREATED BY EXPERTS

The Money

We're trying to raise $1. Anything above that dollar is guacamole.

Get Social With Us

story:
Here's What it is

As most of you know, on October 6th I'll be leaving the continental US and moving to St. Thomas, US Virgin Islands. I'm moving for a much needed change of life, a chance to work on myself, as well as an opportunity to write in a brand-new environment. 
I've lived in Asheville for fourteen years now and it's time to move on. It's always easier said than done, because (like most adventures) there are set backs along the way. In this case it's money. The plane ticket is bought and paid for, and a job is lined up. It's the "survival money" that's going to be the problem. 
No, I'm not talking about housing, or living on a boat.
No, I'm not talking about buying a car or daily sponge-diving exploits. 

What I Need & What You Get

I'm not asking for the world and a bag of gold. I have no delusion about actually raising 3k, but indiegogo made me do it. 

All I'm really asking for is, like, $10 at the very least. From as many people as possible. $10 adds up quickly, so I don't feel the need to be greedy, unless somebody just happens to have a little more they're willing to gift. I mean, jeez, I've left heftier tips at sub-par restaurants. 

And to all of you, I have been your co-worker, your classmate, your acting partner, your crying shoulder, and most importantly, your friend. I don't have much to offer in the way of "perks;" I've got less than 46 days to work off my "thank you debts,"
and I will, if you need help with something I can do. 

HOWEVER, just in case you like swag:

  • For every donation I will provide a warm, fuzzy thank you letter. 
  • Some of you know that I have a slight obsession with making belt-buckles: Yeah, 3/4 of these are Star Trek related, but I think I can manage something else if you're interested in making a more generous donation, of like, $25. Just choose this and tell me what kind of buckle you want,give me an image and a little bit of time.
  • One of my lesser known hobbies is map-making. If you're able to help me out with, say $50 I'll draw a map of your choosing (real, fictional, copywrited, whateve's) Here are some examples a few I made for fun: 

 

  • If I don't get to pay you back before I leave, know that you'll have a friendly face to see during any of your southerly vacations. I promise to take you around, show the sites, and buy at least  the first round of coconut daiquiris.
  • And for $100 dollars I will let you choose what I do! Yeap. Dress me up, take me out, or make me do some wild/crazy/obnoxious activity. 

Cue the Heart Strings

There's more that I'm concerned about. 

It's pretty common knowledge that I'm Type 1 Diabetic. Insulin's expensive. A typical 100ml bottle of insulin (at least the kinds I can use) cost anywhere from $25-100 a bottle, which lasts about two weeks. 

Additionally, food and normal household items seem to be on the jaw-dropping side of expensive down there. 

In the meantime, before leaving, I'm going to be busy selling "things." Things in quotations, yeah. A lot of things that will hopefully supplement what I can't raise through this process.

My friends know that I'd give the shirt off my back and that I'll always go out of my way to help others. Now I'm hoping to cash in some of those karma points.

What if it Don't Work Out, Jamie?

Of course there are always risks and challenges associated with moving somewhere new, and if it doesn't work out I'll be back to Asheville to work off my debt to each of you. Or, over time, just like Grandma did at Christmas and on Birthdays, you may receive a card in the mail with $10. 

The first few months are going to be the toughest, I know, even with the job I've found it takes time to get things going. 

But starting a new life is worth the risk, right? 

On a final note, I've recently had this song by JRR Tolkein in my head:

The Road goes ever on and on
Down from the door where it began.
Now far ahead the Road has gone,
And I must follow, if I can,
Pursuing it with eager feet,
Until it joins some larger way
Where many paths and errands meet.
And whither then? I cannot say.

And so with that, I must go. The next stop is St. Thomas, US Virgin Islands.

Please help, if you can. 

Jamie
story_txt:

As most of you know, on October 6th I'll be leaving the continental US and moving to St. Thomas, US Virgin Islands. I'm moving for a much needed change of life, a chance to work on myself, as well as an opportunity to write in a brand-new environment. 

I've lived in Asheville for fourteen years now and it's time to move on. It's always easier said than done, because (like most adventures) there are set backs along the way. In this case it's money. The plane ticket is bought and paid for, and a job is lined up. It's the "survival money" that's going to be the problem.

story: Celeste was in a car wreck 9 years ago resulting in the loss of both her legs, a light stroke and several broken bones. She wasn't driving but, the driver was her best friend who was killed instantly. She has been the mother to her 3 younger siblings since she was 12. " I just want a car so i can help my dad out with the kids activities and school". The family only has a small Saturn which her dad drives everyday to work leaving her and the kids at home. She did some modeling also which helped her self esteem. A car would also help her not as physical therapy but an overall therapy. "It's hard to be stuck at home when I want to get out of bed and go see what's going on in the world!!"

story:
I don't have diarrhea just yet. But you can bet I will.

It's happening. In just over a month, team Naan-N-Hurry will be leaving on the Rickshaw Run. We'll be covering 2500 miles in 14 days. In a glorified tricycle. From Jaisalmer down the coast to Kochi, India. Which is basically New York City to Mexico City with the possibility of a dance party in Bollywood.

For more about shenanigans, you can check out the website: http://www.theadventurists.com.

Ah, and the more pressing question: WHY?!!!!

WHY? For life, love, and adventure. Lucky for us, infections come with all of those. &Luckier for us, some of those are preventable. The Rickshaw Run is partnering with FRANK Water to decrease the incidence of water-related illnesses and make clean water more accessible. For adventurers, and for folks that just live in places with terrible water.

Let me tell you how terrible that water can be:

  • Globally, diarrhea is the leading cause of illness and death - killing more children than AIDS, malaria, and measles combined. 
  • More than one in six people worldwide - 894M - don't have access to the 20-50L of clean water a day suggested by the UN to ensure their basic needs for drinking, cooking, and cleaning.
  • Almost 1/10 of global disease burden could be prevented from improving water supply, sanitation, hygiene, and management of water resources.
  • 3.575M people die each year from water-related diseases.

Help me raise funds for the Rickshaw Run's charity FRANK Water.

FRANK Water saves lives through funding innovative and sustainable clean water projects in developing countries. Communities are provided with safe, clean water by employing ultraviolet and reverse osmosis technology to filter water and remove diseases causing both chemical and biological contaminants.

The projects are community owned and run, with a priority on community ownership, education and longevity. Each project is managed and operated by local villagers and an affordable user fee model is implemented to ensure sustainability and achieve maximum community uptake well into the future.

Community participation and ownership of projects is essential to their sustainability. The community is involved from the consultation, and support is offered through education and awareness raising about the benefits of clean water. Training and employment opportunities are provided and a village water committee is formed as part of the process.

FRANK's practicing principles are great and their science is solid. 

So for the love of adventure, Bollywood, & clean water, please donate. I might have diarrhea for a couple weeks, but I can pack it up with my privilege and leave. Through sustainable applications via FRANK, however, your dollars will be in India to stay.

story:
I am doing a Charity Skydive in memory of my wonderful Best friend Jamie Peter Knott, who sadly passed away on the 04/11/12 at the age of 15 years old.

Jamie past away in the Royal Manchester Children's Hospital, on the fantastic ward 77, the ward gave Jamie and his family everything which was needed in his stay there. Jamie was such a delightful young man, although he had problems of his own to worry about he never did, he always made other people his priority, He was loving, kind, generous, bubbly and an inspiration to other poorly children. Never once did Jamie complain about his illness.

There is not a word that can summarise Jamie, he was a breath taking cheeky chappy. Doing this skydive for him means so much to me, I feel it will be giving back the thrill of his life, when i jump out of that plane he will be with me laughing and joking all the way down to land.

The money that people kindly donate to me, I am going to personally buy toys and equipment for the ward, and present it them. Any contribution to my jump will be honoured. All you have to do is click 'contribute now' and it guides you through it all :) (ps.. It says using paypal, it still works with anyother card type)

For all those who've kindly sponsored me for my Skydive, which was planned for the 2nd March unfortunately I have to delay the jump, but will be doing it sometime in the near future. For those who've already sponsored me and paid, I will refund your money or I will keep it safe for the jump. Please email me if you're wanting a refund, my email adress is jessicahildreth@hotmail.co.uk  Although the jump is not happening as soon as hoped, it IS still going ahead, Thank you all!x

Thank you so much for reading this.

story:
NOTE: The goal has been reached but funds can still be received and will still count towards the total! Thank you all so much and let's see how far we can take this!

Hey friends,

Thanks so much for stopping by. On November 3rd, 2013 I will run the Auckland Marathon (42.2km). In addition to testing my own physical limitations, I hope to raise awareness and funds for an organization that I strongly believe in called the Tony McClean Nepal Trust.

Tony McClean, a vibrant and much-loved teacher was tragically killed in a 2008 canyoning disaster in the Central North Island that also claimed the lives of six students. Tony had travelled extensively in Nepal and had an incredible passion to address the poverty and injustice in the region. He died leaving behind big, ambitious dreams for the Nepalese people and, amazingly, his family and close friends were inspired to continue his work. This materialised in the form of the Tony McClean Nepal Trust (TNT).

The birth of the trust is a remarkable example of a silver-lining in an otherwise tragic situation. Since it's inception it has gone from strength to strength and is actively making a difference in a place of need.

The work of the charitable trust is centralised in the Lamjung district, which is comprised mainly of Shudra communities. One of TNT's main drives has been to improve the water supply in the region through the provision of water filters. For $65 NZD a household in the Lamjung district can receive a water filtration system that will last for more than ten years and avoid the dire consequences brought about by unsanitary drinking water.

I hope to raise enough funds to provide 10 households with water filters and I would love it if you would consider donating to this cause!

Visit TNT's website at: www.tnt.org.nz for any further information.

Thanks a bunch!

Daniel Adolph

story:
Short Summary

 My name is Christopher Feyrer. Like the infant above, I was born with esotropia, which means my eyes were out of alignment. For me, this lead to binocular suppression -- I can only see with one eye at a time. Both eyes, but never at the same time.   Throughout my life I've had faith in technology to figure out how to fix this issue, and I'm not stopping now. I've researched things like Brock strings, which help people with mine and similar disorders track objects in space to improve their vision and ability to see 3D.

I entered -- and won -- the #ifihadglass contest to begin developing these apps using Glass -- which will be a widely available consumer product with the technology to make these apps happen.  For some, it could mean strengthening a weaker eye through vision exercises.  For others, it could mean accessibilty to things in their peripheral vision. For still others,  it could mean seeing in 3D for the first time using exercises similar to the Brock string.

Four percent of people are born with an eye disorder like esotropia.  Most of us go on to leave functional lives, but why stop with functional? Why not push the envelope to make real 3D vision happen using technology; or at the very least improve ocular acuity and the ability of the eyes to follow one another, increasing self confidence? I feel this could make a huge difference in many people's lives. Tentatively, this app would be called Strong Eyes for Glass.

I also want to go this route so I can meet the Glass team at a pickup location and reiterate how important it is for them to make Glass accessible to people with eye disorders or one eye -- it could change their lives with the right applications, for the better. 

What We Need & What You Get

 $2000 in 2 weeks.  Google was kind enough to extend my purchase window to the 22nd. So it's by then or bust.

The monies will cover the cost of Glass plus travel exepnses to go to the pickup location from my home in the midwest to the East or West coast (whichever has the cheapest flight) to pick up Glass and meet the Google team.

See the exciting list of perks to the right -- be involved with Strong Eyes development, get an eye education seminar, and more!

If the entire goal is not met, funds will go to the AVRO foundation for eye research. http://www.arvo.org/foundation/

I've already reached out to professionals at UW Milwaukee who are excited regarding the potential of this project and are watching closely.  Now all I need is the product in my hands to begin development.

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell EVERYONE about this campaign as FAST as possible. The benefits to people's lives are potentially life changing, I really want to push the envelope.  Tweet, Facebook, Blog, Tumblr, everything!

Learn about esotropia, strabismus and other eye disorders to create awareness of these diseases and the people who desperately need research dollars to help decode the way the brain interprets these signals and fix their gaze.

Donate to foundations like AVRO who do great eye research and are changing people's lives every day.

story:
Our Story

Just a few days ago my husband and I were enjoying a sledding adventure with mother nature when Ken lost control of his inner tube and slid into a tree at a rather fast pace.  The impact resulted in Ken's neck being broken and surgery.  The doctors say that he will need time to recover so at least 3 months before he will be able to work.  The medical bills are piling up and our insurance refuses to pay for a majority of it. We need your help and support. Anything you can do will be appreciated!

The Impact

Ken is the bread-winner of our home and without your help we will not be able to pay our rent, his medical bills, buy food, pay or utilities, and so forth.  I work but my income is truly not even close to enough for us to make it through this rough patch.

What We Need & What You Get

We need help paying for the medical bills and some extra funds to add to my income to pay for our cost of living. If you help us you will know that your contribution won't go unforgotten or unappreciated and that your help made the difference between bankrupt and a quality of life. Thank you so much for all of your help!


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word to your friends and family and kindly ask them to spread the word to their friends and family.
story_txt:
Our StoryJust a few days ago my husband and I were enjoying a sledding adventure with mother nature when Ken lost control of his inner tube and slid into a tree at a rather fast pace.  The impact resulted in Ken's neck being broken and surgery.  The doctors say that he will need time to recover so at least 3 months before he will be able to work.  The medical bills are piling up and our insurance refuses to pay for a majority of it. We need your help and support. Anything you can do will be appreciated!

The Impact
Ken is the bread-winner of our home and without your help we will not be able to pay our rent, his medical bills, buy food, pay or utilities, and so forth.  I work but my income is truly not even close to enough for us to make it through this rough patch.

What We Need & What You Get
We need help paying for the medical bills and some extra funds to add to my income to pay for our cost of living. If you help us you will know that your contribution won't go unforgotten or unappreciated and that your help made the difference between bankrupt and a quality of life. Thank you so much for all of your help!

Spread the word to your friends and family and kindly ask them to spread the word to their friends and family.

story:
Short Summary

Hi there! We, S. (age 39, sperm in great condition) and J. (age 43, eggs old) have been trying for quite some time, both on our own, and with limited, low-tech, medical intervention to bring our baby into the world. We have recently had two biochemical pregnancies (very early miscarriages) and were told that this was actually a good sign! J. can get pregnant, but we just have to find a decent healthy egg.  A good egg.  We're both good eggs, you'd think we could manage to fertilize and implant a few, or one.

We've exhausted our available insurance, which doesn't cover IVF (In Vitro Fertilization) and are going to pay for treatment out of pocket through a well known local fertility clinic. We're going to do this through a combination of indiegogo, savings, acquisition of debts, and a loan against our retirement savings.  We consider ourselves very blessed and very lucky to have found love so late in life because we both dated some real doozies before finding each other. (The humorless vegan, the fake Secret Agent, and the last minute can-you-buy-me-dinner-woman always make us laugh. In retrospect.)

We want to have a baby together and raise it with values like:

  • Knowing the difference between: you're and your; there, they're, and their; and too, two, and to.
  • Hate is not a family value; respect others.
  • Love your neighbor, even if they seem to suck sometimes (especially then.) Our faith is important to us.
  • Take responsibility for your community, and work toward awareness of critical issues affecting other communities beyond your own.
  • Vegetables are good for you; so is ice cream.

The thing is, we're not guaranteed success at this pregnancy thing, but given J's "advanced maternal age" time is running out to try. (And by the way, as you can see, she takes excellent care of herself. She has excellent egg reserve so the odds are better for us than for most geriatric senior potential mommies of her age.)  And we want to try everything we can before giving up, even if it means paying back debts for a few years.  That said, we'd like to reduce the debt we're acquiring which is how your supportive gifts will help.

We're asking for your help funding a single round of IVF medications which will cost between $5000-$7000. And our goal is on the low side of that amount. That seems to be a totally achievable goal, don't you think?

What We Need & What You Get

The whole treatment shebang (see what we did there?) is going to cost around $32,000 for IVF, ICSI, Assisted Hatching, and medications. We're participating in the multi-cycle discount program which gets us two IVF attempts. Medications are separate from the base cost of $18,000 so there are two separate 5-7K rounds to budget and consider.

Between taxes, fees from indiegogo, paypal, and credit cards from your lovely and very much appreciated gifts, even if we reach our goal, we won't get the full amount of one round of medication, so of course, we're hoping to go above and beyond! A number of friends, however, expressed their heartfelt desire to contribute to the opportunity to help us try to bring a little person into the world.

The kicker is... we have to pay the full amount up front... before we start the treatment (in early September). There will be no opportunity to gradually acquire medical bills and pay them off with our incomes. Up front payment, all at once, required. Ouch.

UPDATE: Note to all of our incredibly generous friends, supporters, anonymous contributors from here to Bangalore: If we happen to reach our goal before the end of the campaign, we will, of course, continue to fundraise and plug anything over and above into the other ridiculously expensive treatment costs if you don't mind. The "Governor of Virginia" probing and monitoring appointments, the bloodwork, the anesthesia, the extraction of hopefully some healthy eggs, the injection of S's very special contribution, the hatching of the egg... all of that stuff which your generous spirit is funding.

  • What's in it for you?

Well, for one thing, we will do you the favor of not sending you an ultrasound photo if we're successful, because, come on. If we're successful though, adorable videos and photos.

However, if you gift us in certain amounts, we will thank you with a variety of exquisite and magnificent treats. (See Perks, to the right).  And remember, you're not really purchasing these amazing treats, you are giving us a gift of support that will help us get closer to realizing our dream of having a family. How awesome is that? Helping to create an adorable person?

If we do not reach our goal... then, we'll feel a little pensive, but optimistic, pay a bunch of fees to The Man, and use whatever money we get and put it towards the medications and treatment anyway. Cool?

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people just can’t contribute, and that is completely understandable, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • We ask you to get the word out and make some noise about this medication-funding and baby-production effort.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Say prayers for us, keep us in your thoughts, and send good vibes.

TL; DR: We are nice, responsible people who need help with the costs of medications for IVF baby-making. Please be awesome and help us out. Thank you for reading, considering this, and hopefully, for your gift!

Other Ways You Can Help
We understand that some people just can’t contribute, and that is completely understandable, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

We ask you to get the word out and make some noise about this medication-funding and baby-production effort.
Use the Indiegogo share tools!
Say prayers for us, keep us in your thoughts, and send good vibes.


TL; DR: We are nice, responsible people who need help with the costs of medications for IVF baby-making. Please be awesome and help us out. Thank you for reading, considering this, and hopefully, for your gift!

story:
Short Summary

 

I'm Jane Stewart Townsend. Since August 2009, I have been a Certified Reiki Master. Almost as soon as I received my certification, however, I felt that traditional methods of conveying the healing energy of Reiki as practiced in the United States were not conveying the level of healing energy in the way they were originally discovered and perfected by Dr. Mikao Usui in Japan. It soon came to me that I could use something else about which I knew--ironically, an old Japanese art form--the Temari ball, as a method of conveying a stronger, purer form of Reiki energy to my clients in exactly the places they needed it. Modern Temari balls are made from a Styrofoam base, similar to the Styrofoam balls people attached to old-style car radio antennae to strengthen radio reception. If those balls "pulled in" radio frequencies stronger, I thought, why would balls of the same material not serve to more effectively channel the healing energy of Reiki to the body's energy centers? I then developed a set of Temari balls corresponding to each of the body's energy centers, or Chakras. By placing each ball over its corresponding Chakra, I can convey a more direct, more intense form of Reiki energy to my clients without ever directly laying my hands upon their bodies.

 

Shortly after my article "Temari Reiki: A new hands-off approach to traditional Reiki" was published in the International Journal of Nursing Practice, I was invited to a conference on cancer research in San Francisco by the OMICS Group, scheduled to take place October 19-23. Soon after that I was invited to present my article at that conference. I currently do not have the funds available to attend that conference, nor do I have funds available to do the kind of subsequent research into the way Temari Reiki affects clients with different forms of cancer, or other severe and chronic illnesses, including Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD). In order for me to best apply--and to allow others to effectively apply--the healing effectiveness of Temari Reiki in the broadest ways possible, I need to be able to tell the medical community, directly, about what I have discovered, and to effectively conduct further research into its healing properties. To do this, quite frankly, I need money. And that is why I have turned to Indiegogo and its fund-raising forum for  help. And why I've turned to you, my potential funders, for the help I need.

You, as a funder, will help me attend a conference that is vital to getting the message about Temari Reiki out to the international medical community. But more importantly, it is vital to get word out of the successful results I and my clients have had with this new form of Reiki, and to allow it to help the largest number of people possible.

 

What We Need & What You Get

I need to raise $12000 by October 7, 2013. A portion of these funds will go towards my attending the OMICS Group Cancer Conference in San Francisco October 19-23, 2013. At that conference I'm scheduled to present and discuss my article "Temari Reiki: A Hands-Off Approach To Energy Healing" to the conference's attendees from around the world. The remainder of the funding will go towards further research into the effects of Temari Reiki in people with severe and chronic illness, including different forms of cancer and other severe and chronic illnesses, including those diagnosed with PTSD (Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder).

My "perk" offerings include:

--A custom-made Temari ball and a three-session Temari Reiki gift certificate for a contribution of $1000 or more;

--A three-session Temari Reiki gift certificate for a contribution of $750;

---A two-session Temari Reiki gift certificate for a contribution of $500, and

--A single-session Temari Reiki gift certificate for a contribution of $250.

The funds I do raise will still help me to make the trip to the conference (if possible) and will make a big difference in my ability to do more crucial research into the effectiveness of Temari Reiki.

 

The Impact

I'm asking for your help because I need it to allow me to attend this conference, and to do subsequent research. Temari Reiki has helped many people by conveying energy to them to allow them to heal from many different ailments, from the chronic to the severe to the terminal. The OMICS Cancer Conference is bringing together dozens of physicians, scientists and researchers from around the world to discuss and share their findings of effective ways to treat cancer, and they feel that Temari Reiki, based upon my experiences and those of my clients, is a successful, non-traditional means of doing so.

Your contribution will help not only me, but those who can  be helped by treatment of their illnesses through the healing powers of Temari Reiki. What you give to my efforts will not only allow me to attend this conference and to spread the word about Temari Reiki and its successes to an international medical audience, it will allow my to conduct more research into the healing properties of this new form of Reiki, and to work with thos who have a variety of medical conditions which Temari Reiki has the potential to help. This new form of Reiki, and those who will provide it, has the potential for a wide impact in healing those with chronic and severe illnesses.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Welcome to the Hurtle Medical Fund

My name is Jessica and I have known Beky for more than 7 years.  I was very privileged to meet Joe on their first date, which was over 3 years ago.  They are an amazing couple and were just married in June of 2013.  To add to this great family are their two daughters, Rae(12th grade) and Emmie(6th grade).  After just a couple of months of blissful marriage they found out that Joe has a mass on his brain, which will require surgery.  The best brain surgeon in the southeast will be performing his craniotomy on September 20th at CMC Charlotte. They are all very strong individuals and are thinking positively as they overcome this next "hurtle" in their lives. 

 
This campaign is to raise funds to help assist with the financial obligations related to Joe's upcoming operation.  Luckily, they do have insurance.  However, the deductible is $3000 and they will have to pay 20% of the final bill.  Not to mention all the other costs associated with an operation of this magnitude....transportation to/from doctors appointments, prescriptions, time away from work, etc.  I hope that by raising funds through the kindness and generosity of others, that this family will be able to focus on the important things - Joe's recovery from surgery and getting him back into good health.

What We Need & What You Get

The funding raised here will go directly to the Hurtle family.  It will be used towards the cost of surgery, hospital stay, medications, and living expenses while Joe is recovering.  The GREAT part of this campaign is that the family will receive all donations made even if we are unable to meet the $10,000 goal I have set.

You might be asking, "why $10,000?"  Well, that's a great question!!  Truly, it is not known *exactly* how much is needed for this family.  We know that their insurance deductible is $3,000, but there's also that 20% co-pay.  The other $7,000 would be 20% of $35,000 additional medical bills.  The costs add up quickly in a procedure like this.


Perks!!!

  • *HUG* $25 contribution perk -  the perk at this level is a virtual hug via the internet.  Just know that every small amount, even if it isn't $25, is GREATLY appreciated. 
  • *LETTER* $100 contribution perk - the perk at this level will be a virtual hug via the internet AND a personalized thank you letter from the Hurtle family.
  • *SURPRISE* $500 contribution perk - the perk at this level will be all the other perks , as well as an additional surprise!!

Other Ways You Can Help

So, you can't really afford to make a contribution at this time....that doesn't mean that you can't help!!  All you have to do is keep this family in your thoughts.  You can also share this campaign with your friends, colleagues, strangers...it doesn't matter.  Just help us get the word out about this wonderful family that is in need.


Thank you for taking the time to read through this campaign.  Thank you in advance for any assistance that you are able to provide...it is going to a good cause. Please feel free to contact me directly if you have any questions about this family. ~Jess

story:
Geared Wheels Help Wheelchair Users Regain Independence 

Reinventing the Wheel.

Just over five years ago a young, bright mechanical engineering student at the University of Illinois was sitting on the campus quad watching students race to get across the large sprawling campus to get from class to class in time. As he watched students walk and run and bike across the quad he noticed students in wheelchairs struggle as they pushed themselves to make it to class in time. In that moment Scott Daigle thought, "I bet I could design some way of making wheelchairs easier to push and more efficient".


Over many busy days and long nights of hard work and innovation the IntelliWheels Easy Push geared wheels were created! The Easy Push wheels are a light-weight, low profile geared wheel that use a simple gearing design that makes pushing twice as easy! 

The IntelliWheels Easy Push


Introducing the Intelli-team.


The lean and innovative Intelli-team of mechanical engineer Scott Daigle, disability and community health expert Marissa Siebel, international wheelchair athlete and motivational speaker Joshua George have taken Scott's idea of geared wheels and are ready to introduce them to the World! 

Get to know the Intelli-Team!

The Intelli-team has worked together over the past three and a half years incorporating, securing funding, prototyping, testing, manufacturing, assembling, and are now ready to introduce the IntelliWheels Easy Push to the World!


IntelliWheels Launches Easy Push Wheel

"Our goal is to create technology that makes a positive impact in a person's life. By consistently using client feedback during development of the IntelliWheels Easy Push wheels we are confident that we have accomplished that goal and are excited to get our wheels into the hands of the people who need them." - Marissa Siebel, Co-founder of IntelliWheels.

We Need Your Help to Keep IntelliWheels Rolling!

IntelliWheels needs your support to take Scott's idea from the middle of the cornfields of Champaign, Illinois into the homes and hands of wheelchair users over the world. 

$50,000.00 will go towards spreading the word and delivering the Easy Push wheels to those who need it worldwide.


The $50,000.00 will specifically go towards educating healthcare providers, durable medical professionals, and end users about the Easy Push wheels as well as provide the Intelli-team the means to travel to important trade shows worldwide. We believe that in order to successfully reach individuals in need and provide them with a more independent lifestyle we need to reach healthcare providers and professionals in the durable medical industry worldwide.


  • $20,000.00 directly funds a worldwide education campaign for healthcare providers, wheelchair users, and durable medical professionals to show how the Easy Push geared wheel keeps wheelchair users active and allows them to live a more independent lifestyle.
  • $30,000.00 will go toward funding the Intelli-team as they attend important durable medical trade shows, disability expos, and meet with individuals and organizations worldwide promoting and delivering more independence for wheelchair users through the IntelliWheels Easy Push. 


Helping The World Go Round.

The world population in 2008 was 6.7 billion. With 1% of the world population estimated to be wheelchair users, we could effectively estimate there are  67 million wheelchair users worldwide.  

Your contributions will help IntelliWheels reach more users and successfully introduce more wheelchair users to a greater sense of independence.


$25.00 - IntelliWheels with thank you for your support providing you with an IntelliWheels decal and T-Shirt to help you spread the word about independent mobility along with updates from the Intelli-team as they bring independence to people of all ages and abilities.  

$50.00 -  You will receive the IntelliWheels decal, T-shirt, and your name on the IntelliWheels website as a sponsor. You will receive a certificate of appreciation from the Intelli-team and a signed photo of IntelliWheels partner and international wheelchair racer Joshua George.

$75.00 -  For every 10 of these gifts, we will donate 1 set of IntelliWheels Easy Push wheels to a nursing home, children's hospital, or a veteran's hospital in need.  By pooling your resources with other sponsors, you can provide independent mobility to someone in need.

If desired, your name will appear on our website and to whom wheels were donated.

$300.00 -  Along with the gifts associated with the previous dollar amounts you get to choose an item of your choice to be featured in the video blog "What can Josh George pull with the IntelliWheels Easy Push?!?", items include and are not limited to; a car, a line of shopping carts, a boat on a trailer, a baby stroller, your uncle in his recliner...

$1,000.00 - Along with previous gifts you will also receive a set of IntelliWheels Easy Push wheels to keep or gift to a person, charity, Veterans Hospital or facility of your choice. If desired, your name will appear on our website and to whom the wheels were donated.

$10,000.00 - Along with the previous gifts you will also receive 12 sets of IntelliWheels Easy Push wheels to keep or gift to a person, charity, Veterans Hospital or facility of your choice.

If desired, your name will appear on our website and to whom wheels were donated.


Please Help IntelliWheels provide mobility options for aging individuals, pediatric wheelchair users, individuals with disease progression, or others that simply need a little help regaining their independence. 

Check us out at www.intelliwheels.net

and follow us on Twitter and Facebook at IntelliWheels

Thank you!

Sincerely,

Scott, Josh and Marissa 

The Intelli-team
story_txt:
Geared Wheels Help Wheelchair Users Regain Independence 
Reinventing the Wheel.
Just over five years ago a young, bright mechanical engineering student at the University of Illinois was sitting on the campus quad watching students race to get across the large sprawling campus to get from class to class in time. As he watched students walk and run and bike across the quad he noticed students in wheelchairs struggle as they pushed themselves to make it to class in time. In that moment Scott Daigle thought, "I bet I could design some way of making wheelchairs easier to push and more efficient".



Over many busy days and long nights of hard work and innovation the IntelliWheels Easy Push geared wheels were created! The Easy Push wheels are a light-weight, low profile geared wheel that use a simple gearing design that makes pushing twice as easy! 
The IntelliWheels Easy Push












Introducing the Intelli-team.



The lean and innovative Intelli-team of mechanical engineer Scott Daigle, disability and community health expert Marissa Siebel, international wheelchair athlete and motivational speaker Joshua George have taken Scott's idea of geared wheels and are ready to introduce them to the World! 
Get to know the Intelli-Team!
The Intelli-team has worked together over the past three and a half years incorporating, securing funding, prototyping, testing, manufacturing, assembling, and are now ready to introduce the IntelliWheels Easy Push to the World!



IntelliWheels Launches Easy Push Wheel
"Our goal is to create technology that makes a positive impact in a person's life. By consistently using client feedback during development of the IntelliWheels Easy Push wheels we are confident that we have accomplished that goal and are excited to get our wheels into the hands of the people who need them." - Marissa Siebel, Co-founder of IntelliWheels.
We Need Your Help to Keep IntelliWheels Rolling!
IntelliWheels needs your support to take Scott's idea from the middle of the cornfields of Champaign, Illinois into the homes and hands of wheelchair users over the world. 
$50,000.00 will go towards spreading the word and delivering the Easy Push wheels to those who need it worldwide.



The $50,000.00 will specifically go towards educating healthcare providers, durable medical professionals, and end users about the Easy Push wheels as well as provide the Intelli-team the means to travel to important trade shows worldwide. We believe that in order to successfully reach individuals in need and provide them with a more independent lifestyle we need to reach healthcare providers and professionals in the durable medical industry worldwide.




$20,000.00 directly funds a worldwide education campaign for healthcare providers, wheelchair users, and durable medical professionals to show how the Easy Push geared wheel keeps wheelchair users active and allows them to live a more independent lifestyle.

$30,000.00 will go toward funding the Intelli-team as they attend important durable medical trade shows, disability expos, and meet with individuals and organizations worldwide promoting and delivering more independence for wheelchair users through the IntelliWheels Easy Push. 









Helping The World Go Round.
The world population in 2008 was 6.7 billion. With 1% of the world population estimated to be wheelchair users, we could effectively estimate there are  67 million wheelchair users worldwide.  
Your contributions will help IntelliWheels reach more users and successfully introduce more wheelchair users to a greater sense of independence.






$25.00 - IntelliWheels with thank you for your support providing you with an IntelliWheels decal and T-Shirt to help you spread the word about independent mobility along with updates from the Intelli-team as they bring independence to people of all ages and abilities.  

$50.00 -  You will receive the IntelliWheels decal, T-shirt, and your name on the IntelliWheels website as a sponsor. You will receive a certificate of appreciation from the Intelli-team and a signed photo of IntelliWheels partner and international wheelchair racer Joshua George.
$75.00 -  For every 10 of these gifts, we will donate 1 set of IntelliWheels Easy Push wheels to a nursing home, children's hospital, or a veteran's hospital in need.  By pooling your resources with other sponsors, you can provide independent mobility to someone in need.
If desired, your name will appear on our website and to whom wheels were donated.
$300.00 -  Along with the gifts associated with the previous dollar amounts you get to choose an item of your choice to be featured in the video blog "What can Josh George pull with the IntelliWheels Easy Push?!?", items include and are not limited to; a car, a line of shopping carts, a boat on a trailer, a baby stroller, your uncle in his recliner...
$1,000.00 - Along with previous gifts you will also receive a set of IntelliWheels Easy Push wheels to keep or gift to a person, charity, Veterans Hospital or facility of your choice. If desired, your name will appear on our website and to whom the wheels were donated.
$10,000.00 - Along with the previous gifts you will also receive 12 sets of IntelliWheels Easy Push wheels to keep or gift to a person, charity, Veterans Hospital or facility of your choice.
If desired, your name will appear on our website and to whom wheels were donated.




Please Help IntelliWheels provide mobility options for aging individuals, pediatric wheelchair users, individuals with disease progression, or others that simply need a little help regaining their independence. 
Check us out at www.intelliwheels.net
and follow us on Twitter and Facebook at IntelliWheels
Thank you!
Sincerely,
Scott, Josh and Marissa 
The Intelli-team

story:
If you are a mum, chances are you’ve experienced this: You go to a restaurant that was listed as child-friendly on Yelp or TripAdvisor. Turns out that they haven’t got a baby changing station, have never heard of baby bottle warming, oh wait - you can’t even get the pushchair through the door!

WowMum™ sets out to re-define the term child-friendly.

We have devised a FREE app (yes you read it right, free) and a website for parents to search for the right places to go when they're out and about. So whether they're looking for buggy-friendly cafés, emergency diaper changing, soft-padded play areas for toddlers, WowMum's got it covered.



Although we have over 15,000 child-friendly locations in major cities in the UK, we're not everywhere. We're also constantly getting requests from mums and dads all over the world.

To help more parents go out and about with their little ones, we're asking for your help.

The funds will primarily go to data collection, allowing our team to locate more child-friendly spots and covering more towns. We will also work on new features based on parents requests: food allergy notes, best times to go, family parking, where to go for first aid, to name a few.

For this campaign, we can only work with locations within the UK and America, but give us a little bit of time, and we'll go further and further.

The Main Entrée

With your pledge, simply tell us where you are, and we'll pinpoint child-friendly spots (we call the WowSpots) for you, your little ones, and your community, at areas of your choosing. Think about it as a Concierge service designed specially for you, but you can benefit hundreds of parents at the same time!

Don't have small children at the moment? You can generously gift the WowSpots to your nieces and nephews, your god children, your grandchildren, or friends with kids, surrounding their homes with new and exciting places to go.

With different perk packages, your WowSpots can be made to order to suit your needs. Choose between WowSpot types, categories, and facilities.

 

A Little Extra

Teaming up with illustrator PicNic, WowMum is pleased to present our amazing supporters a beautiful set of artwork, London A-Z, aptly named after the iconic London A-Z Street Atlas. PicNic's illustrations showcase some top attractions and scenes in London, and works beautifully as postcards or alphabet cards for the little ones.

These prints would look marvelous on your wall too.

To deck out the out-and-about gears of our WowMums and WowDads, we've created some wonderful GelaSkins cases and skins, available for a wide variety of devices, from mobile phones (iPhones, Samsung handsets) to iPod, Kindle and Apple laptops.

Jenn and Shruti, the two co-founders of WowMum, met in school in San Francisco, but fate brought them to London years later. They both worked as award-winning art directors in ad agencies including Ogilvy & Mather and Goodby Silverstein & Partners, stewarding global brands like Unilever and Adobe. The two began the concept of WowMum in 2012, and Nic, then a senior engineer at Microsoft, joined the team, followed by Aparna, an account director and former O&M colleague.

It all happened on a particularly fine spring day.

We were out with a friend, pushing her newborn baby girl Sophie around London Bridge. All of a sudden, little Sophie started to get, well, a bit unhappy. It took 20 minutes of our peeking into random restaurants, interrogating waiters, crossing the Thames, to finally locate a café that was buggy-friendly, had a baby changing station, with a comfortable enough atmosphere for Sophie’s mum to breastfeed.

That was when we thought: There’s got to be an easier way.

The fundamental idea for WowMum™ was conceived in that café that afternoon. We want to help all the little Sophies and their mums find child-friendly places easily, swiftly, elegantly (the exact opposite of our exasperated state that day) when they are out and about.

Download the WowMum app for free, or visit us on www.wowmum.com, but please keep in mind that the coverage is limited to major cities in the UK for now.

WowMum on iTunes / Google Play
WowDad on iTunes / Google Play

story:
HELP FATIMA AND OTHER LIKE HER AROUND THE GLOBE!

Fatima is a woman in sub-Saharan Africa who lost her baby because she couldn't get an emergency C-section.  Her remote village was 20 miles walking from the nearest health facility.  But the time she reached the hospital, the baby was in distress and there was no surgeon available to provide the emergency surgery.  Now, she can't have more children because of all the birth trauma she endured

What if you could impact the life of a mother and child today?  

  • Cesarean sections are not available in many countries worldwide.  In fact, in some very poor countries, a mother in need of a C-Section may only have a 1 in 12 chance of having access to one! And her risk of death during child birth may be as high a 1 in 8
  • But C-Sections are only one type of surgery that is necessary in developing countries.
  • Trauma is a neglected epidemic in developing countries,causing more than five million deaths each year, roughly equal to the number of deaths from HIV/AIDS, malaria and tuberculosis combined!
  • GSC is working to change this by cataloging the availability of surgical and pain services in low income countries

By revealing where the needs are, and partnering with those who can meet the needs for emergency surgery, GSC will change this reality

 Who We Are

  • The Global Surgical Consortium (GSC) is a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization dedicated to documenting the resources gaps necessary to build surgical and anesthesia infrastructure in low-income countries.
  • At GSC, we envision a world without barriers to safe surgery and anesthesia. The GSC Vision is to provide the data and improvement measures to insure safe and cost-effective emergency and essential surgical care to all who need it.
  • It costs approximately $10,000 to survey one low-income country for our database.  Costs for database creation will exceed $100,000 over the next year and then at least $500,000 to create an internet-based open-source platform over the next five years.

 What We Need & What You Get

We need $10,000 now to start building our database infrastructure.  Ultimately, this project will cost over $500,000 to complete all the surveys and build the open-source database.  This database will be instrumental in directing resources to low-income countries and avoiding duplication of efforts by nongovernmental organizations worldwide.

The Impact

This database is the first of its kind.   It is valuable to the world, global organizations and donors because it pinpoints the needs and creates awareness for the importance of surgery and the live’s lost when emergency surgery is not available.  We have successfully collected data in 7 countries, providing the information in an open source format to assist global organizations in targeting their programs.  YOU can impact lives donating to this project allowing us to continue the data collection needed today to provide surgery in the future. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us spread the word about our campaign!

  • Tell your friends!
  • Share this campaign on Facebook!
  • Go to our website and sign up for our newsletter!
  • Offer your time to our organization - we need programmers, writers, and other specialists!

Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools to help us make some noise!

story:
The Project

My name is Elizabeth Armentino-Burd. I am a yoga teacher and a personal trainer. I have been working with people with Parkinson's Disease as well as other movement disorders since 2007. 

After volunteering my time teaching the class for two years, I was approached by Maine Medical Center and became part of the team of the Learning Rescource Center. I also teach at the M.O.G. in South Portland, (Medically Oriented Gym) Natural Fitness in Portland, and Ocean View in Falmouth.

For several years, people who have taken my classes have asked me to make this DVD. Through their encouragement it is finally happening! This has become my passion and my calling.

Over the years, I have seen so many lives truly transformed through yoga. This program has helped those people gain strength, balance, and flexibility leading to a significantly better quality of life. I feel so fortunate to be able to witness ( part of ) such amazing changes in peoples' lives.

The completion of this DVD is a huge part of my plan to be able to help more people through yoga! Your contribution will have a profound impact on many lives, something you can really pat yourself on the back for!

 The Nitty-Gritty

I have been amazingly fortunate and blessed with supportive friends and family. (As you will see by my AWESOME perks that were all donated by friends and family) 

I have had people also help with this project with donated shooting space, students have donated their time, the videographer and sound engineer even donated THEIR time! (many hours!)

I am hoping that by letting your know how many people believe in me and this work, that you will too.

The project is almost ready and here's what your funds will help:

Production: Paying the editor for the countless hours of work!

Duplication: 300-500 copies made to start! Printed by a  local company!

Promotion: All things I need to get the word out! I hope to get postcards printed with all the information to mail out. I would also love to hear from you about promotion ideas!

Extra:  If I go over my goal, the money will go toward trademarking the name and other business needs. 

 ANY AMOUNT WILL HELP!!

It's really true, folks. ANY AMOUNT EVEN ONE DOLLAR WILL HELP!!

YOU DON'T EVEN HAVE A DOLLAR?

I have been there! The good news is, you can still help! Foward this to everyone you know! Put on your thinking cap, do you know anyone in the medical profession who may come in contact with those folks with Parkinson's or other movement disorders? Do you yourself know anyone with Parkinson's?

I also welcome any ideas around the promotion of this DVD.

THANK YOU!!  THANK YOU!!!! THANK YOU!!!!!!

story:
Meet Baby Aspen!

Baby Aspen was born on December 28th 2011, a beautiful 7lbs 4 oz and 21 1'2 inches long. The first two months of Aspen's life were bliss. But, in March 2012, everything changed.

Aspen battles with a Medical Mystery. Her symptoms include: GERD, Apnea, Acrocyanosis,Syncope & Heart Shunt. Her Diagnosis is Unknown.

Aspen requires a sleep apnea monitor. Her parents have gone through troubles and battles to get this sleep apnea monitor, which was approved by a doctor, but because Aspen has an unknown diagnosis, with medical conditions, Medicaid does not want to cover it, and wants the Pittman Family to pay $400 a month, which just is impossible to do. Without this monitor, Baby Aspen can stop breathing at any moment.

Baby Aspens Medical Bills are covered through State Medicaid, however mom and dad do not have transportation to specialist appointments, which requires gas. Mom and Dad need help getting Aspen to these appointments!

Mom is expecting, and currently has a daughter, age 3, Kora, along with Aspen. Dad works, but all his income goes to rent. Mom is out of work because of Aspens multiple health conditions and the required care she needs.

Mom and Dad face their electric bill going off at any time. Along with their phone, and internet, which they are willing to sacrifice as long as baby Aspen gets the medical care she needs. Mom however, needs a phon to be able to communicate with Aspen's medical doctors.

Mom and Dad are stressed. Financially. Emotionally. Mentally. Any parent who has a special needs child with medical conditions feels the concerns and issues that this family has. It takes a toll.

This fundraiser is to raise funds to help out the Pittman Family.

We hope to be able to raise $500.00. With this $500.00, The Pittman Family can use this money to take Aspen to her specialists, use this money for electricity, diapers, and anything that Aspen needs. It would go towards the family needs.

If you can not donate, what you can do is say a simple prayer of healing for Aspen, and the Pittman Family. A simple Prayer is good enough!

The way it works is your money you can donate via paypal or credit card. The money we collect via paypal account will be transferred to a prepaid debit card, where the Pittman Family can use the money to purchase Aspens Sleep Apnea Monitor and get the things they need.

 

We Want to Thank you for your help, and please continue to pray for baby aspen and the Pittman Family.

 

April Driesse: Manager of Fundraiser

Amberlai: Baby Aspens Mother

story:
Riley and Kristen are going through training to teach Riley how to become a medical alert service dog. She will learn to detect the onset of migraines Kristen frequently experiences as a result of a traumatic brain injury she sustained in 2008. Riley will also help Kristen with coping with social anxiety and symptoms of PTSD. She will help Kristen finish her bachelor's degree and go back to work.


Service dogs can be very expensive, necessary, family members. This is the initial campaign to raise funds to help offset some of Riley's puppy expenses through December which outline as follow:

_______________________________________________________________________

 +UPDATE:

Riley is all up to date on vaccines and I have decided to dedicate all funds received during this fundraiser to go towards her spay and microchip. I have been paying for the training and everything else on my own. I sincerely appreciate your donations towards my service dog! ~Kristen

Here is the estimate from the vet so you know where the funds will be directed toward:

Procedure or Dispensed Item                                Charge
Ovariohysterectomy, Canine (over 50lbs)                395.00
Preanesthetic Injection                                          0.00
*Chemistry Profile - Small                                     0.00
*Complete Blood Count                                        0.00
*PT / aPTT Coagulation Tests (canine)                   0.00
*IV Catherization & Fluid Administration                  0.00
*Out-Patient Hospitalization                                  0.00
Microchip Application                                             52.00

Total estimate charges...                                     $447.00

All funds received that surpass $447 and reach toward the original goal of $1,200 will go toward paying for our trainer and certification process.


Feel free to contact us with any questions! ServiceDogRiley@gmail.com

Thank you for considering helping us out, it means a ton to us to be able to teach Riley how to help Kristen manage her migraines and PTSD better!

Can't contribute now but interested in helping out later? This is just the beginning, our next fundraiser will focus on funds for training and certification.


We also have an on going wishlist of items at www.facebook.com/servicedogriley
story_txt:
Riley and Kristen are going through training to teach Riley how to become a medical alert service dog. She will learn to detect the onset of migraines Kristen frequently experiences as a result of a traumatic brain injury she sustained in 2008. Riley will also help Kristen with coping with social anxiety and symptoms of PTSD. She will help Kristen finish her bachelor's degree and go back to work.
Service dogs can be very expensive, necessary, family members. This is the initial campaign to raise funds to help offset some of Riley's puppy expenses through December which outline as follow:
_______________________________________________________________________
 +UPDATE:
Riley is all up to date on vaccines and I have decided to dedicate all funds received during this fundraiser to go towards her spay and microchip. I have been paying for the training and everything else on my own. I sincerely appreciate your donations towards my service dog! ~Kristen
Here is the estimate from the vet so you know where the funds will be directed toward:
Procedure or Dispensed Item                                ChargeOvariohysterectomy, Canine (over 50lbs)                395.00Preanesthetic Injection                                          0.00*Chemistry Profile - Small                                     0.00 *Complete Blood Count                                        0.00*PT / aPTT Coagulation Tests (canine)                   0.00*IV Catherization & Fluid Administration                  0.00*Out-Patient Hospitalization                                  0.00Microchip Application                                             52.00Total estimate charges...                                     $447.00All funds received that surpass $447 and reach toward the original goal of $1,200 will go toward paying for our trainer and certification process.
Feel free to contact us with any questions! ServiceDogRiley@gmail.com
Thank you for considering helping us out, it means a ton to us to be able to teach Riley how to help Kristen manage her migraines and PTSD better!
Can't contribute now but interested in helping out later? This is just the beginning, our next fundraiser will focus on funds for training and certification.
We also have an on going wishlist of items at www.facebook.com/servicedogriley

story:
Help Fund the Medical Training and Sustainability Project in the Small Village outside Abetifi-Kwahu

  • Plant a fully stocked medical center in the middle of the village
  • Fund regular visits by medical professionals from the area
  • Fund regular visits by medical professionals from the USA and elsewhere to provide training

The Story of Adopt One Village

Emmanuel Anim-Sackey left his village in Abetifi-Kwahu, Ghana in search of a better life. He achieved success as a U.S. postal worker in West Orange, NJ. But he longed to help support the village he left behind. So he founded Adopt One Village, a nonprofit organization that provides U.S. donations to this desperately poor village.

For his efforts, Emmanuel was recognized as West Orange, NJ Citizen of the Year in January 2009. Later, he was recognized as Humanitarian of the Year by the U.S. Postal Service at a ceremony in Washington DC. Emmanuel is grateful for the recognition but he knows there is much more to do in his beautiful village home.

Emmanuel collects donations of used clothes and other supplies at the Adopt One Village warehouse in West Orange, NJ. He and his wife, Angela, are there daily collecting, sorting and preparing goods to be shipped to this impoverished region in Ghana. In addition, Emmanuel travels at least twice a year with volunteers from Adopt One Village to bring supplies and aid to Abetifi Kwahu. As the President of the Board, Emmanuel ensures that his vision for bringing sustainability to this region is always the main focus.

Adopt one Village is 100% run by volunteers. We have no full time staff and we do not generally pay for services.  We rely on volunteers to perform many of the most critical steps towards the success of our efforts.  Your support goes directly to the place of need - whether that be to transport medical supplies or fund the trip of a doctor or dentist to the area.

More information about the goals and efforts of Adopt One Village can be found at www.AdoptOneVillage.org

What We Need

We need to raise approximately $10,000 before the January, 2013 trip so we can arrange these items during our next trip,  Our volunteers on the ground in Ghana work on this project almost daily, but it takes a visit to insure that funds are properly distributed and that services are actually rendered.

(Any additional funds donated will help maintain the project well into the future)

We have already acquired a building in the center of the village, but it needs to be retrofitted to receive supplies and equipment.
 
We have already performed a vast majority of the physical transformation of the building that has become "The Life Clinic." We still need to do the following:
 
  • Stock the building full of simple but essential medical supplies. (taking place in July, 2012)
  • Fund local medical professionals so they can make regular visits from the hospital in Abetifi to the rural village medical center. This medical center will serve hundreds of adults and children within the rural village and surrounding area.
  • Fund medical professionals and other projects to enhance the center as needed: We have a number of medical volunteers and professionals who have gone over and served. However, we would like to hold simple training sessions so that the local people can learn how to take care of minor wounds and issues on their own using the stock of supplies we will help maintain.

The Impact is Great...

One of our board members visited the rural village with Emmanuel in January 2010. At that time, many of the children had never even seen a Band Aid before.

A good number of the children had festering wounds on their legs and feet from infections. An impromptu medical mission was performed by the four volunteers who traveled over with Emmanuel using only their travel kits and some local supplies purchased as needed. Some of the children that were met during that trip have since passed away due to easily preventible causes. A number of the adults and parents have also passed prematurely because simple medical care is not available in the area.

Since then, we have acquired a building located at the center of the village, directly between two school buildings that is easily accessible by all of the children and their families. We have sent over three teams to work on the building (as well as the schoolhouse) and have added a new roof, security features to keep supplies safe, a new concrete pad around the building to help control erosion and more. 

During the July 2012 trip, we will be installing cabinets within The Life Clinic. Critical supplies are arriving in late June via container shipment and will be distributed to the clinic as well as some of the impoverished local hospitals. A team of administrative and medical professionals will be on hand to organize the clinic and set it up so a local team of doctors can regularly visit.

The 2012 team is not just made up of the professionals mentioned above but also includes a group of teens from the USA who will deliver customized "care packages" to the local kids including hand written letters and other items to help encourage continued education.

A small donation today could literally save a life tomorrow...  And that is why we are doing much of what we do.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • You can spread the word about our campaign to friends, family and colleagues.
  • You can adopt us as your charity for a youth group, womans' program, school project, etc.
  • You can follow us on Facebook at http://www.facebook.com/adoptonevillage
  • You can sponsor children and teachers on the http://www.AdoptOneVillage.org web site to help them learn how to bring sustainability to their village.

Help Fund The Life Clinic, Medical and other Educational Projects and change Ghana one Village at a Time with us! We appreciate your support!

 

 

Created by Joe Agro

Some of Joe's AOV Activities

  • Involvement in most infrastructure related projects
  • Helps prep the volunteers prior to the trip and assists with logistics of projects while on site in Ghana
  • Oversees web site, Facebook and electronic media storage projects
  • Involved in all things related to mechanical equipment

Some of Joe's Other Activities, Accomplishments, Education, etc.

  • Business owner, AutoDrill LLC
  • Served in Chairman's Executive Response Center, AT&T Corp. (World HQ)
  • Served as Executive Assistant Team Leader, Arthur Andersen BC (Metro NY)
  • Served as a volunteer youth leader (20 years) and former Board Member, The Life Christian Church (West Orange, NJ)
  • Security team organizer and consultant
  • Current board member, Adopt One Village

Joe is also a motorcycle enthusiast. He hopes to start an adventure riding company / club based in Ghana. If he is successful at launching the effort, the proceeds from tours will support the vision of Adopt One Village. Participants will be able to visit the actual area(s) served by Adopt One Village and even participate in single or multi-day activities if desired. The roads are incredible and adventure calls!

story:
THE FACTS

Over 2 billion people in the world suffer from biologically polluted water. Their drinking sources are often wells or rivers contaminated with biological parasites, germs and viruses. These issues keep them in a constant state of Gastrointestinal distress often causing diarrhea and illness. They simply cannot keep food down and get little nutrition out of what they do eat. They are literally starving to death because of the poor quality of their water.

 The lack of fresh water can be an insurmountable obstacle to living a good life. Without it people can't stay healthy, they can't stay in school or keep working. Without clean fresh water, the possibility of breaking out of the cycle of poverty is incredibly slim.

Here is where 5 Minute Water comes into play. Our self-contained unit creates 32 oz. of biologically fresh water in under five minutes with no chemicals, using totally natural UVC light. This simple to use product can create enough fresh water for a family of 4 in less then 15 minutes. It uses either a solar recharger/battery, 4 AA batteries or AC current and can be used anywhere in the world were fresh water is needed.

HOW IT WORKS - (watch the video above)

To use 5 Minute Water, you first clarify the contaminated water through a filter device or a T-shirt to remove rocks, sand and debris. (This is not necessary when water comes from the tap or well without debris but is still contaminated) Fill the 32 oz jar with the contaminated and clarified water. The 5 Minute Water UVL is then screwed onto the jar and plugged in for 5 minutes. The ultraviolet light then kills ALL the parasites, germs and viruses. Our certified lab tests prove that just 2 minutes of UVC exposure creates biologically fresh water. It is a simple yet effective non-chemical all natural way to deliver life saving water to families around the world. With the 5 Minute Water system people with biologically infected wells and rivers can dramatically improve their health and nutrition.

CHECK OUT OUR LAB RESULTS AT THE BOTTOM OF OUR GALLERY PAGE

 WHY WE NEED FUNDING

With funding we can tool up to mass production and reduce the cost of each unit. Our goal is to sell a complete system, which includes a storage bottle, UVL unit and its jar, battery, and solar recharger/battery for just $129.00. We can then sell the complete system wholesale for just $99.00. The wholesale price will also be available to qualified mission programs and philanthropic groups.
Imagine changing the lives of an entire family for just $99! We are hoping to raise $150,000, to reduce the cost of each unit, and get 5 minute water out into the world.  The lab tests are done, and our first model designs are now being tested and used in the real world.  With your help, we can tool up and bring biologically fresh water to those in need.  

For every $50,000 additional dollars we raise, we will donate 250 units ($25,000 worth of systems) to mission organizations. We have begun a relationship with Mission Volunteer Partners and other organizations, which will help us distribute systems to families in need. Their website is http://www.missionvolunteerpartners.com
